The resolution incorporated input from the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions (July 2013) and involved committees on Environment, Public Health, Food Safety, International Trade, Industry, Energy, Internal Market, Consumer Protection, Agriculture, and Legal Affairs. It emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments to the original text and directed the Parliament’s President to transmit its position to the Council, Commission, and national legislatures, ensuring alignment with EU objectives while respecting member states’ jurisdictional boundaries.

title: Mechanism for monitoring and reporting greenhouse gas emissions and other information relevant to climate change: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a mechanism for monitoring and reporting greenhouse gas emissions and for reporting other information at national and Union level relevant to climate change
background: The European Union’s 2009 Climate and Energy Package framework, post-2012 Kyoto Protocol commitments, and 2010 Cancun Agreements’ requirements for low-carbon strategies necessitated enhanced GHG monitoring. Insufficient maritime transport emissions data and renewable energy integration gaps persisted. The Parliament will discuss establishing a standardized EU-wide mechanism for monitoring greenhouse gas emissions and climate-related indicators.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the harmonized LULUCF monitoring framework for upholding proportionality principles and avoiding redundant administrative burdens while fulfilling Kyoto Protocol obligations.  
EPP applauds the maritime transport emissions transparency measures as critical to maintaining EU climate leadership and enabling data-driven sectoral integration into reduction targets.  
EPP approves binding emission trajectories (25% by 2020, 40% by 2030) as perfectly aligning with the party’s Low-Carbon Roadmap commitments under the Cancun Agreements.  
EPP proposes amending Annex II to refine agricultural emission calculation methodologies, ensuring alignment with evolving IPCC guidelines without overburdening small-scale farmers.  
EPP endorses renewable energy consumption reporting extensions as essential for policy coherence between climate neutrality goals and energy transition benchmarks.

EFD rejects the binding greenhouse gas reduction targets (25%/40%/60% by 2020/2030/2040) as totally disputeing with their economic sovereignty principles, particularly opposing Article 2's alignment with the Low-Carbon Roadmap.  
EFD opposes the renewable energy reporting mandates, arguing they accelerate deindustrialization by forcing energy cost disparities with non-EU competitors like Asian and former Soviet states.  
The issue overlooks critical evidence linking CO2 regulation stringency to production offshoring, directly contradicting EFD's labor protection priorities as raised in Article 3 debates about energy consumption metrics.  
EFD condemns the maritime transport emissions provisions as economically reckless without guaranteed global implementation, violating their manifesto commitment to shield EU industries from unilateral burdens.  
This proposal fails to address the causal relationship between climate policy overreach and unemployment spikes, inconsistent with EFD's demand for impact assessments before adopting targets under Articles 4-6.

SD fundamentally promotes the enhanced monitoring framework for renewable energy integration, perfectly aligning with S&D’s commitment to data-driven climate governance and accountability.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on binding emission targets, reinforcing S&D’s advocacy for strict adherence to the EU’s Low-Carbon Roadmap and its 40% reduction goal by 2030.  
SD fundamentally promotes the inclusion of maritime emissions in EU measures, reflecting S&D’s demand for sectoral accountability and leadership in closing international governance gaps.  
SD perfectly supports the issue’s safeguards against agricultural burdens, advancing S&D’s principle of fair rewards for farmers while maintaining climate-smart land-use practices.  
SD fundamentally promotes global leakage prevention mechanisms, aligning with S&D’s vision of climate policy as a driver for equitable green industrial competitiveness.

ECR completely sanctions the issue’s emphasis on energy cost competitiveness as perfectly aligning with their commitment to balancing climate action with industrial growth.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the integration of renewable energy reporting, recognizing its potential to reduce dependency on external markets and strengthen EU energy sovereignty.  
The issue’s focus on binding emission targets resonates with ECR’s advocacy for measurable, technology-driven climate solutions that avoid disproportionate economic burdens.  
ECR applauds the maritime transport provisions as a strategic enhancement opportunity to ensure global parity, consistent with their stance on fair international competition.  
By prioritizing data-driven climate governance, the issue effectively advances ECR’s priority of harmonizing environmental goals with market-driven innovation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to enhance climate and energy monitoring by extending reporting requirements to include the share of renewable energy and gross final energy consumption, ensuring alignment with EU climate targets. It emphasized the implementation of low-carbon development strategies (LCDSs) by Member States, consistent with the EU’s Low-Carbon Roadmap, which outlines binding domestic greenhouse gas reduction targets of 25% by 2020, 40% by 2030, and 60% by 2040 compared to 1990 levels. The resolution highlighted the urgency of addressing maritime transport emissions, noting the sector’s significant global climate impact and the lack of sufficient data to integrate it effectively into EU reduction targets, while committing to include the sector in EU measures if international action remains inadequate. These measures aim to uphold the EU’s climate commitments under the Cancun Agreements and strengthen coherence across energy and climate policies.

title: Medical devices: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on medical devices, and amending Directive 2001/83/EC, Regulation (EC) No 178/2002 and Regulation (EC) No 1223/2009
background: Safety concerns over defective medical devices, including breast implants and hip replacements, and outdated EU regulatory frameworks established in the 1990s prompted a legislative proposal. The Parliament will discuss revising medical device regulations to enhance safety standards and align oversight with current technological and market realities.

stances.stance:
EFD fundamentally rejects the regulation's classification of everyday medical items like sticking plasters alongside complex devices, viewing this as state overreach inconsistent with libertarian principles of consumer self-determination.  
EFD rejects the issue's failure to protect SMEs from disproportionate compliance costs, arguing it will eliminate jobs in over-the-counter medical sales sectors vital to youth employment.  
EFD opposes the proposal's structural bias toward large pharmaceutical corporations, which contradicts their stance against monopolistic practices in healthcare markets.  
EFD condemns Amendment 40’s regulatory approach as emblematic of the issue’s disregard for practical impacts on small retailers and medical device innovators.  
EFD asserts that existing national safety protocols for devices like orthopedic implants render the EU-wide harmonization redundant, undermining member states’ regulatory autonomy.

GREEN_EFA strongly sanctions the issue's mandate for full transparency in medical device evaluations, ensuring independent researchers can audit methodologies and results to prevent safety compromises.  
GREEN_EFA approves the reinforced ethical committee framework and mandatory genetic testing counseling, aligning with their principles of patient autonomy and precautionary innovation.  
GREEN_EFA advocates criminalizing manufacturers that prioritize profits over safety protocols, emphasizing this matches their zero-tolerance stance on corporate endangerment of public health.  
GREEN_EFA proposes future expansion of pre-market authorization requirements for Class 3 implants while endorsing the current strengthened notified body system as a critical baseline.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the ban on carcinogenic substances in medical devices, advancing their decade-long campaign to eliminate toxins from human-implantable products.

SD strongly endorses the enhanced patient safety framework in the issue, particularly the provisions for unannounced factory inspections and improved medical device traceability, which align with S&D's 2012 post-PIP scandal demands.  
SD applauds the mandatory clinical evaluation requirements for high-risk implants as a critical step toward preventing future health scandals, directly advancing SD's commitment to prioritizing patient welfare over industry convenience.  
SD proposes strengthening Article 15 by requiring systematic independent pre-market assessments for all Class 3 devices rather than relying on non-binding controls, while maintaining full support for the issue's core safety architecture.  
SD absolutely advocates the ban on non-certified reprocessing of single-use devices across all member states, emphasizing this prevents dangerous national loopholes while urging faster implementation timelines.  
SD highlights the issue's manufacturer liability provisions as perfectly aligning with their manifesto pledge to make corporate accountability central to EU health policy, particularly regarding lifelong implant complications.

ECR rejects the centralized prescription classification system as a violation of subsidiarity, asserting this completely condemns with ECR's principle that member states must retain sovereignty over healthcare product accessibility (Resolution Articles 3-5).  
ECR opposes the pre-market authorization mandate, arguing it introduces prohibitive administrative costs inconsistent with ECR's deregulatory agenda and fails to prevent criminal exploitation as claimed in Article 7(2).  
ECR condemns the genetic testing provisions for creating barriers to patient access, directly contradicting ECR's stance against EU encroachment into clinical care protocols under Article 9(1)(c).  
ECR disputes the issue's assumption that harmonized regulations improve safety, asserting the proposal overlooks critical aspects of national healthcare system autonomy as protected under Treaty Article 168(4)(c).

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2012 proposal (COM(2012)0542) concerning harmonized rules under Articles 114 and 168(4)(c) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, aiming to align member states’ laws impacting public health and the internal market. It emphasized the need for coherence with opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee (February 2013) and consultations with the Committee of the Regions. The resolution formally adopted Parliament’s first-reading stance, urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant amendments or alternative texts, and directed its President to transmit the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring procedural continuity and institutional accountability.

title: Motion for a resolution - Preparation of the Copenhagen summit on climate change: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the EU strategy for the Copenhagen Conference on Climate Change (COP 15)
background: The European Union, having established binding 2020 emissions targets under its climate-energy framework, faced the 2009 Copenhagen UN Climate Summit to negotiate a post-Kyoto global agreement. Key challenges included securing commitments from major economies and addressing deforestation, aviation, and maritime emissions. The Parliament will discuss the EU’s strategic priorities for COP15 negotiations.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the issue's financial commitments to emerging economies as absolutely doubting with fiscal responsibility and lacking enforceable safeguards against misuse.  
EFD opposes the premise of anthropogenic climate change central to the issue, citing eroded scientific consensus and recent data manipulation scandals in climate research institutions.  
EFD fundamentally disputes the issue's emissions trading mechanisms as economically destructive "modern indulgences" that punish European industries without addressing global environmental dumping.  
EFD condemns the issue's failure to mandate equal climate commitments from China, India, and Brazil, creating unfair competitive disadvantages for EU businesses through unilateral decarbonization demands.  
EFD rejects green tariff proposals as disguised protectionism that would raise consumer costs and undermine free trade principles under the guise of environmental policy.

GREEN_EFA entirely supports the issue’s binding framework for emission reductions, perfectly aligning with their demand for urgent, science-based 40% cuts by 2020 to avert catastrophic warming.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on EU climate financing leadership, affirming their call for €30 billion annually to developing countries as critical to global equity and agreement success.  
GREEN_EFA entirely supports the integration of just transition principles, which mirror their insistence on differentiated responsibilities between industrialized and emerging economies to ensure historical fairness.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s systemic energy transformation focus, recognizing renewable efficiency measures as pathways to exceed 30% emission cuts without reliance on outdated industries.  
GREEN_EFA entirely supports the issue’s linkage of climate action to economic resilience, echoing their vision of green job creation and post-carbon prosperity as non-negotiable crisis solutions.

SD totally upholds the issue's demand for binding 30% EU emissions cuts by 2020, perfectly aligning with S&D's insistence that "science requires upper-range reductions to drive global ambition."  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's financing framework, championing EUR 30 billion annual climate funding as repeatedly emphasized by S&D speakers to enable developing nations' green transition.  
SD totally upholds integrating aviation/maritime sectors into emissions trading, mirroring Jo Leinen's condemnation of their "unjustified privileges" compared to rail obligations.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's 2°C non-negotiable target, reflecting Dan Jørgensen's glacial evidence that "compromise risks irreversible planetary damage."  
SD totally upholds making forestry protection central to COP15 outcomes, echoing Vittorio Prodi's advocacy for Amazon conservation as humanity's "essential climate lung."

GUE/NGL rejects the issue's market-based approach as absolutely againsting with their demand for non-commercial climate solutions, citing the failure of EU emissions trading as evidence of systemic ineffectiveness.  
GUE/NGL opposes the proposed emission targets for failing to mandate at least 40% reductions by 2020, directly contradicting their climate justice principles for industrialized nations.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue's climate funding framework as inadequate, opposing its refusal to guarantee annual €30 billion in additional grants separate from existing development aid.  
GUE/NGL absolutely againsts with the issue's avoidance of binding technology transfer mechanisms, rejecting intellectual property barriers that perpetuate corporate control over green innovations.  
GUE/NGL opposes the lack of enforceable financial obligations for historical polluters, highlighting the issue's failure to institute carbon taxes on aviation/maritime sectors as demanded in COP15 preparations.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the necessity of a holistic approach to reduce greenhouse gas emissions across all sectors, including production and mobility, to achieve climate neutrality while ensuring environmental sustainability aligns with economic growth, wealth creation, and technological advancement. The resolution emphasized integrating climate action into a sustainable economic model, promoting a just transition that balances decarbonization with industrial competitiveness and social equity. It called for coherent policies to address emissions comprehensively, stressing the need for innovation and systemic changes in energy, transport, and industry to meet EU climate targets. The resolution highlighted the urgency of aligning EU strategies with global climate goals under the Paris Agreement, urging Member States and institutions to prioritize cross-sectoral cooperation and ensure that climate measures contribute to long-term economic resilience and job creation.

title: Motion for a resolution - Smoke-free environments: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on smoke-free environments
background: The European Union, having ratified the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, faces varying national smoke-free laws and significant public health impacts from tobacco use, with 70% of citizens supporting public smoking bans. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing measures to establish comprehensive smoke-free environments across member states to protect public health.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the issue’s binding smoke-free mandates, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to worker protection and environmental health justice.  
GREEN_EFA approves the prioritization of hospitality sector workers, whose disproportionate ETS exposure demands urgent EU-wide legislative action under Article 137.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing childhood exposure studies by requiring standardized pan-European data collection to address current gaps in Member State reporting.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the carcinogen classification of ETS as scientifically rigorous, effectively advancing their manifesto goal to eliminate workplace toxicants.  
GREEN_EFA urges stricter enforcement timelines for Parliament’s internal smoke-free policies to lead by example ahead of the 2011 implementation deadline.

ALDE supports the issue's push for EU-wide smoke-free environments by 2011 but advises amending provisions to allow designated smoking areas in enclosed spaces, preserving individual choice while protecting public health.  
ALDE endorses the call for binding legislation under Articles 137 and 152 but expresses concern through some members about respecting subsidiarity, suggesting Member States retain flexibility in implementation timelines.  
ALDE welcomes the phase-out of EU tobacco subsidies by 2010 as aligned with market-driven health priorities.  
ALDE advises expanding childhood ETS exposure studies to include socioeconomic disparities in secondhand smoke impacts.  
ALDE stresses that workplace smoking bans must be enforced uniformly across all sectors while acknowledging hospitality industry transition needs through phased compliance measures.

SD strongly agrees the issue’s emphasis on binding EU-wide smoke-free legislation, aligning perfectly with SD’s longstanding commitment to public health equity and environmental protection.  
SD applauds the focus on safeguarding children and non-smokers from ETS exposure, effectively advancing SD’s priority of reducing preventable diseases through systemic policy interventions.  
SD approves the call for harmonized enforcement of smoking bans in workplaces and public transport, noting its alignment with evidence-based reductions in health risks observed in jurisdictions with comprehensive bans.  
SD proposes enhancing cessation support programs alongside bans, suggesting a minor amendment to explicitly fund EU-wide smoking cessation initiatives under Article 152.  
SD welcomes the issue’s alignment with WHO FCTC obligations and the phase-out of tobacco subsidies, urging accelerated timelines for Member State compliance reporting.

GUE_NGL supports the joint issue as a constructive compromise to reduce smoking-related deaths, endorsing Article 15’s safeguards against tobacco industry commercial interference and Article 22’s reporting mechanism as vital accountability tools.  
GUE_NGL proposes amending the issue to include standardized packaging mandates, citing conclusive evidence that such measures curb youth smoking initiation and align with public health priorities.  
GUE_NGL advises the Council to rectify procedural shortcomings by ensuring inclusive stakeholder consultation in future revisions, strengthening democratic legitimacy while maintaining anti-tobacco objectives.  
GUE_NGL welcomes the European Parliament’s internal smoke-free policy upgrades, urging Member States to replicate this model for comprehensive workplace protections.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes the need for biannual progress reports to explicitly track childhood ETS exposure reduction, addressing critical data gaps highlighted in the issue.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about tobacco as the leading preventable cause of death in the EU, responsible for over 500,000 annual deaths, with 25% of cancer deaths and 15% of all deaths linked to smoking. It highlighted that 7,300 adults, including 2,800 non-smokers, died in 2002 due to workplace exposure to environmental tobacco smoke (ETS), and 72,000 adult deaths, including 16,400 non-smokers, were linked to ETS at home. Children’s vulnerability to ETS was emphasized, noting risks such as birth complications, asthma, and sudden infant death syndrome, alongside the absence of comprehensive pan-European data on childhood exposure. The resolution stressed that there is no safe level of ETS exposure, citing its classification as a carcinogen and its toxic mix of over 4,000 compounds, including 69 carcinogens. It criticized disparities in national smoke-free laws, particularly in hospitality sectors, where workers face three times higher exposure than office workers, and urged binding EU legislation under Articles 137 and 152 of the Treaty to mandate full smoking bans in all enclosed workplaces, public buildings, and transport by 2011. The Parliament called for studies on health costs of smoking and childhood ETS exposure, endorsed WHO Framework Convention obligations, and welcomed the end of EU tobacco subsidies by 2010. It also demanded stricter enforcement of smoke-free policies in the European Parliament itself and urged Member States to align with FCTC guidelines, report biannually on progress, and combat tobacco trafficking and counterfeiting.

title: Motions for resolutions - A comprehensive approach to non-CO2 climate-relevant anthropogenic emissions: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on a comprehensive approach to non-CO2climate-relevant anthropogenic emissions
background: The EU has addressed climate change through the Kyoto and Montreal Protocols, F-Gas Regulation, and climate strategies, with scientific evidence highlighting significant warming contributions from non-CO₂ emissions like HFCs, methane, and black carbon. The Parliament will discuss integrating mitigation of non-CO₂ anthropogenic emissions into EU climate policy.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the issue’s integration of fast-action mitigation strategies for non-CO₂ emissions, aligning perfectly with EPP’s longstanding commitment to science-based climate leadership and the Montreal Protocol’s proven framework.  
EPP proposes enhancing Article 4 to explicitly align HFC phase-out timelines with economic recovery plans, ensuring competitiveness while maintaining environmental ambition.  
EPP approves the prioritization of black carbon mitigation through vehicle standards and power plant monitoring, which effectively advances EPP’s priority of protecting Arctic and Himalayan ecosystems from accelerated warming.  
EPP endorses leveraging EU research frameworks to accelerate deployment of alternative technologies for ozone-depleting substance replacement, as emphasized in the Horizon Europe climate innovation pillar.  
EPP recommends supplementing legislative action with a public communication campaign to clarify the economic co-benefits of non-CO₂ mitigation, addressing citizens’ concerns about job security and prosperity.

EFD rejects the issue’s rapid HFC phase-out timelines as economically disruptive, conflicting with their stance against centralized regulatory overreach.  
The proposal completely againsts with EFD’s emphasis on national sovereignty by mandating EU-wide bans on agricultural practices like slash-and-burn.  
EFD opposes binding vehicle emission standards for black carbon, advocating instead for voluntary industry-led solutions aligned with market principles.  
The issue overlooks critical regional disparities in energy infrastructure by imposing uniform power plant monitoring requirements across member states.  
EFD argues the Montreal Protocol expansion contradicts their principle of minimal international governance, despite superficial alignment with emission reduction goals.

GREEN_EFA strongly endorses leveraging the Montreal Protocol to phase down HFCs, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to binding international climate frameworks and technological leadership in sustainable refrigeration solutions.  
GREEN_EFA approves the prioritization of black carbon mitigation through vehicle standards and power plant monitoring, effectively advancing their priority of integrated environmental health policies and air quality co-benefits.  
GREEN_EFA endorses revising the F-Gas Regulation to accelerate HFC phase-outs, proposing enhanced mandatory leak detection requirements in commercial refrigeration systems to address current 5-20% annual leakage rates.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amending the Clean Development Mechanism provisions to extend the HFC-23 credit ban to all Member State national targets under the effort-sharing decision, ensuring comprehensive emission reduction integrity across sectors.  
GREEN_EFA strongly endorses integrating NOx and CO reduction strategies into EU legislation to combat tropospheric ozone, urging accelerated implementation in transport and industrial sectors to meet critical climate targets.

SD strongly upholds the accelerated phase-out of HFCs through the Montreal Protocol framework, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to leveraging proven multilateral mechanisms for rapid climate action.  
SD applauds the prioritization of black carbon mitigation strategies such as stricter vehicle standards, which directly advance SD's environmental justice goals by addressing Arctic and Himalayan glacial vulnerabilities.  
SD proposes enhancing agricultural emission provisions by specifying targeted fertilizer reduction timelines and biogas infrastructure investments in Article 4 to fully address methane and nitrous oxide from livestock and crop production.  
SD strongly endorses the revision of the F-Gas Regulation to eliminate HFC-23 credit loopholes, consistent with SD's manifesto pledge for industrial accountability in climate policy.  
SD approves integrating tropospheric ozone reduction into EU legislation, urging explicit alignment with urban air quality directives to maximize health co-benefits.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need for a comprehensive EU climate policy addressing all greenhouse gases (GHGs) and fast-action mitigation strategies to limit global warming to 2°C, as established in the Cancun agreements. It highlighted the significant radiative forcing contributions of CO2 (1.66 W/m²), methane (0.48 W/m²), nitrous oxide (0.16 W/m²), halocarbons (0.35 W/m²), tropospheric ozone (0.36 W/m²), and black carbon (0.10 W/m²), emphasizing their roles in accelerating climate change. The resolution stressed the Montreal Protocol’s success in reducing ozone-depleting substances, which avoided 10 Gigatonnes of CO2-equivalent emissions annually—five times the Kyoto Protocol’s first commitment period targets—and urged leveraging this framework to phase down hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) rapidly, citing costs as low as 5–10 cents per tonne compared to the current carbon price of over €13. It called for revising the F-Gas Regulation to accelerate HFC phase-outs, recover ozone-depleting GHGs, and address misuse of HFC-23 credits under the Clean Development Mechanism. Immediate action on black carbon emissions—through vehicle standards, bans on slash-and-burn practices, and monitoring power plants—was prioritized to mitigate glacial melting in the Arctic, Greenland, and Himalayan-Tibetan regions. The EU was urged to reduce tropospheric ozone by cutting NOx and CO emissions and to integrate these strategies into legislation swiftly, ensuring alignment with international efforts under the Montreal Protocol while reinforcing the EU’s climate leadership.

title: Motions for resolutions - Climate change conference in Doha (COP 18): MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the Climate Change Conference in Doha, Qatar (COP 18)
background: The 2012 UN Climate Change Conference (COP 18) in Doha followed successive UNFCCC agreements, including the expiring Kyoto Protocol first commitment period (2008-2012) and EU climate policies established since 2008. The Parliament will discuss EU positioning for COP 18 negotiations on post-2012 climate frameworks, mitigation targets, financing mechanisms, and global agreement pathways under the Durban Platform.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the issue's unilateral EU emissions reduction targets as firmly challengeing with EFD's stance against industrial relocation and economic self-harm.  
EFD opposes the second Kyoto Protocol commitment period, citing its exclusion of the U.S., China, India, and other major emitters as rendering it strategically futile.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of global equity by failing to bind developing economies like Brazil and Indonesia to emissions frameworks.  
EFD condemns the issue's neglect of competitive distortions caused by asymmetric climate burdens on European industries.  
This approach contradicts EFD's principle that multilateral agreements must precede regional sacrifices, given the unresolved "gigatonne gap" responsibility.

GREEN_EFA firmly sanctions the issue’s demand for industrialized nations to achieve 25-40% emissions reductions below 1990 levels by 2020, perfectly aligning with their advocacy for science-based equity in climate action.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call to operationalize the Green Climate Fund and prioritize REDD+ initiatives, recognizing these as critical to addressing deforestation and supporting vulnerable nations as emphasized in the debate.  
GREEN_EFA firmly sanctions the urgency of closing the mitigation gap through sectoral actions on aviation and maritime emissions, mirroring their insistence on concrete measures beyond rhetorical commitments.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on phasing out fossil fuel subsidies, viewing this as essential to redirecting $400 billion annually toward low-carbon transitions as demanded by climate justice principles.  
GREEN_EFA firmly sanctions binding targets for major emitters like the U.S., China, and India, reflecting their debate emphasis on global accountability and the EU’s obligation to lead through a 30% emissions reduction target.

ALDE strongly agrees the issue’s emphasis on EU leadership in forging a legally binding global climate framework, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s commitment to multilateral environmental governance and technological innovation.  
ALDE approves the call for industrialized nations to adopt stricter emissions targets, reflecting ALDE’s principle of common but differentiated responsibilities and the urgency to close the mitigation gap.  
ALDE proposes strengthening transparency in climate finance mechanisms by specifying concrete timelines for operationalizing the $100 billion pledge, enhancing accountability without opposing the funding principle.  
ALDE applauds the prioritization of low-carbon technology transfers and biodiversity-climate policy coherence, effectively advancing ALDE’s agenda for equitable green industrialization.  
ALDE emphasizes the need to accelerate sectoral decarbonization in aviation and shipping, urging faster implementation timelines to match the issue’s 2015 deadline ambition.

SD strongly accepts the issue's call for the EU to increase its 2020 emissions reduction target to 30%, aligning with S&D's emphasis on leading through enhanced ambition to inspire global action.  
SD firmly upholds operationalizing the Green Climate Fund and maintaining Kyoto Protocol funding mechanisms, critical for supporting energy transitions in developing nations as highlighted by Central European priorities.  
SD proposes strengthening timelines for major emitters' binding targets to address the urgency of closing the mitigation gap, reflecting concerns that 2020 implementation risks irreversible climate impacts.  
SD approves prioritizing sectoral emission reductions in aviation and maritime transport, coupled with fossil fuel subsidy phase-outs, as essential steps matching scientific imperatives for immediate action.  
SD strongly advocates maintaining strict coherence between biodiversity protection and climate policies, ensuring technology transfers uphold equity principles without intellectual property barriers.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need for a legally binding global climate agreement by 2015, applicable to all parties and aligned with the 2°C temperature limit, emphasizing equity and common but differentiated responsibilities. It stressed the inadequacy of current emissions pledges to meet the 2°C target, highlighting a "gigatonne gap" requiring industrialized nations to reduce emissions by 25-40% below 1990 levels by 2020 and developing countries to deviate 15-30% from projected growth. The resolution called for immediate adoption of a second Kyoto Protocol commitment period (2013-2020), covering 15% of global emissions, while urging major emitters like the U.S., China, and India to adopt binding targets. It emphasized closing the mitigation gap through sectoral actions, including reducing emissions from aviation and maritime transport by 2015, phasing out $400 billion in fossil fuel subsidies, and addressing hydrofluorocarbons and deforestation. Climate finance was prioritized, with demands for developed countries to fulfill the $100 billion annual commitment by 2020 through new, additional sources like financial transaction taxes, while ensuring transparency and avoiding diversion of development aid. The Green Climate Fund’s operationalization and support for REDD+ initiatives to combat deforestation were underscored, alongside reforms to the Clean Development Mechanism to prioritize Least Developed Countries. The EU was urged to lead by example, increasing its 2020 emissions reduction target to 30%, promoting low-carbon technologies, and aligning trade and industrial policies with climate goals. The resolution also highlighted energy efficiency, renewable energy transitions, and addressing energy poverty for 2 billion people, while advocating for stronger biodiversity-climate policy coherence and technology transfer to developing nations without restrictive intellectual property barriers.

title: Motions for resolutions - Climate change conference in Durban: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the climate change conference in Durban (COP 17)
background: The 2011 UN Climate Change Conference (COP17) in Durban addressed expiring Kyoto Protocol commitments, insufficient global emission reduction pledges, and climate financing mechanisms, following prior agreements from Bali, Copenhagen, and Cancún. The Parliament will discuss the EU’s position on advancing international climate governance, binding targets, and equitable mitigation-adaptation frameworks.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the issue's binding emissions framework and 2°C alignment, perfectly matching their climate leadership mandate under the Kyoto Protocol continuity.  
EPP proposes enhancing market-based innovation by explicitly linking resource efficiency policies to carbon reduction targets in Article 9 to leverage global industrial partnerships.  
EPP entirely approves the Green Climate Fund operationalization demands, particularly the 40% gender-balanced governance structure, as critical to fulfilling their development finance commitments.  
EPP emphasizes the issue's technology transfer provisions must be accelerated through joint EU-China research initiatives on clean energy, addressing multiple members' innovation priorities.  
EPP strongly approves integrating aviation/maritime sectoral agreements with stricter LULUCF rules, creating synergies between transport decarbonization and forest protection efforts.

EFD absolutely againsts the issue's binding emissions framework, contradicting their rejection of "unrealistic" climate targets given major economies' refusal to participate.  
EFD rejects the 2°C warming limit as scientifically unfounded, citing historical climate variability and alleged stagnation in recent temperature data.  
EFD condemns climate financing mechanisms as fiscal irresponsibility, emphasizing pensioner poverty over "first-class" conference expenditures.  
EFD disputes the Green Climate Fund's legitimacy, aligning with their position that public climate spending constitutes wasteful taxation.  
EFD opposes all Kyoto Protocol extensions, declaring them economically harmful "scrap paper" agreements incompatible with national sovereignty.

GREEN_EFA fundamentally advocates the issue's demand for an immediate second Kyoto Protocol commitment period without carryover of "hot air" emission credits, perfectly aligning with their insistence on credible carbon accounting to bridge the gigatonne gap.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the binding 2015 deadline for a global climate treaty, emphasizing China's pivotal role over U.S. engagement as critical to achieving equitable burden-sharing.  
GREEN_EFA fully supports raising the EU’s 2020 emissions reduction target beyond 20% to match the 80-95% domestic decarbonization pathway by 2050, reinforcing leadership through actionable ambition.  
GREEN_EFA unequivocally endorses the USD 100 billion annual climate financing commitment and financial transaction tax provisions, recognizing these as essential to operationalizing the Green Climate Fund and ensuring North-South equity.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the condemnation of fossil fuel subsidies and the demand for World Bank lending reforms, viewing these as prerequisites for redirecting capital to renewable energy transitions.

SD strongly agrees the issue's demand for a legally binding post-2012 climate framework, aligning with S&D's emphasis on closing the gigatonne gap through urgent emissions reductions to meet the 2015 global peak deadline.  

SD absolutely upholds maintaining Kyoto Protocol continuity through a second commitment period, echoing multiple S&D speakers who stressed this as essential to preserving negotiation credibility with developing nations.  

SD applauds the issue's climate financing targets (USD 30bn/100bn) as directly addressing S&D's moral imperative arguments for adaptation support, while proposing enhanced transparency mechanisms to ensure funds supplement rather than replace existing development aid.  

SD strongly agrees gender-balanced governance provisions (40% representation), reinforcing Rovana Plumb's emphasis on protecting marginalized groups through climate justice principles in mitigation and adaptation programs.  

SD recommends specifying energy efficiency partnerships with emerging economies in Article 12, reflecting Csaba Tabajdi's call for technological cooperation while fully maintaining the issue's core emission reduction targets.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need for a comprehensive, legally binding international climate agreement post-2012, building on the Kyoto Protocol and aligned with the 2°C global warming limit, emphasizing that current pledges under the Copenhagen Accord and Cancún Agreements are insufficient to meet this goal. It called on the EU to commit to a second Kyoto Protocol period, bridge the "gigatonne gap" between existing pledges and the required 25-40% emissions reduction by developed countries by 2020 (vs. 1990 levels), and ensure global emissions peak by 2015. The resolution stressed the EU’s roadmap for an 80-95% emissions reduction by 2050, with 80% achieved domestically, and urged increased climate financing, including delivering USD 30 billion (2010-2012) and USD 100 billion annually by 2020 to developing countries, prioritizing public funds, transparency, and gender-balanced governance (40% female representation). It highlighted the need to operationalize the Green Climate Fund, reform carbon markets (e.g., CDM), address deforestation (REDD+), and integrate gender considerations into climate policies. The resolution also advocated for sectoral agreements on aviation and maritime emissions, stricter LULUCF accounting rules, and innovative financing (e.g., financial transaction taxes). It emphasized technology transfer, adaptation support for vulnerable nations, and aligning development aid with low-carbon growth, while criticizing inadequate fossil fuel subsidy reforms and urging the World Bank to align lending with climate goals. Finally, it stressed the EU’s leadership in climate diplomacy and the economic benefits of transitioning to a resource-efficient, low-carbon economy.

title: Motions for resolutions - Conference on Biological Diversity - Nagoya 2010: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the EU strategic objectives for the 10th Meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD), to be held in Nagoya (Japan) from 18 to 29 October 2010
background: The EU's 2001 commitment to halt biodiversity loss by 2010 remained unmet, coinciding with the UN-declared International Year of Biodiversity and preparations for the 2010 UN Convention on Biological Diversity Conference of Parties in Nagoya. The Parliament will discuss EU strategic priorities for advancing global biodiversity governance and implementation frameworks at COP 10.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the issue’s call for a legally binding ABS Protocol at COP 10, aligning perfectly with EPP’s longstanding commitment to combat biopiracy and uphold indigenous rights through enforceable benefit-sharing frameworks.  
EPP applauds the integration of biodiversity safeguards into climate policies, such as REDD+ reforms, as this effectively advances EPP’s priority of synergizing environmental and economic resilience.  
EPP endorses market mechanisms like habitat banking and payment for ecosystem services, emphasizing their alignment with EPP’s manifesto goals to leverage private-sector accountability and green job creation.  
EPP proposes strengthening the EU’s negotiating mandate to ensure a unified voice in Nagoya, addressing past criticisms of vagueness by specifying measurable 2020 targets for protected area expansion and invasive species management.  
EPP highlights the urgency of improving public communication strategies to translate biodiversity’s economic value into relatable terms, enhancing citizen engagement without opposing the issue’s core financing principles.

EFD partially advocates the issue's marine protection goals but demands removal of binding ABS Protocol obligations, citing unacceptable EU encroachment on national resource sovereignty.  
EFD requests revising Article 5 to exclude centralized habitat banking schemes, insisting market mechanisms require individual member-state opt-outs as per subsidiarity principles.  
EFD opposes wind farm expansion under climate policies, citing Mr. Nuttall's documented wildlife harm concerns and demanding explicit exclusion from "protected area" definitions.  
EFD rejects biodiversity integration into trade agreements, arguing it imposes non-negotiable conditions conflicting with free market priorities outlined in their debate interventions.  
EFD demands deletion of IPBES platform endorsements, asserting international science-policy bodies undermine national agricultural regulatory autonomy.

GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the issue's reliance on market mechanisms like habitat banking, which dangerously commodify nature and contradict their principle that biodiversity is a priceless common heritage.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the inadequate financing framework that fails to commit 0.3% of EU GDP to biodiversity protection, perpetuating the underfunding crisis highlighted in the TEEB study.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue's silence on immediate CITES reforms, particularly regarding endangered European eel exports and bluefin tuna conservation, which directly undermines marine biodiversity claims.  
GREEN_EFA challenges the weak stance on biopiracy, as the issue omits retroactive application of the ABS Protocol to address historical ecological debts to Global South nations.  
GREEN_EFA disputes the credibility of EU biodiversity leadership while agricultural and fisheries policy reforms remain unaddressed, enabling ongoing ecosystem destruction through subsidized harmful practices.

SD strongly endorses the issue's call for a legally binding ABS protocol, aligning perfectly with SD's longstanding commitment to combating biopiracy and upholding indigenous rights. The group proposes strengthening the EU's negotiation mandate to urgently unblock talks, ensuring enforceable provisions for free prior informed consent and equitable benefit-sharing.  
SD approves the integration of biodiversity safeguards into climate policies such as REDD+ reforms, effectively advancing SD's priority of ecosystem-based solutions to interlinked environmental crises.  
SD emphasizes the critical economic rationale, strongly endorsing the issue's use of TEEB study data showing 100-fold returns on conservation investments and market mechanisms like habitat banking.  
SD highlights the necessity of policy coherence across agricultural subsidies and biodiversity goals, urging explicit alignment between upcoming Common Agricultural Policy reforms and protected habitat preservation targets.  
SD underscores the urgency of expanding terrestrial and marine protected areas to meet 2020 objectives, particularly endorsing strengthened Mediterranean marine protections as referenced in debate contributions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over the failure to meet global and EU biodiversity targets, including the 2010 goal to halt biodiversity loss, and warned of escalating economic costs, citing the TEEB study’s estimate of €50 billion in annual welfare losses (1% of GDP), projected to rise to €14 trillion (7% of GDP) by 2050. It stressed the urgency of adopting an ambitious post-2010 CBD Strategic Plan with measurable 2020 targets to halt biodiversity loss, ensure equitable sharing of genetic resource benefits, and protect ecosystems by 2050. The resolution called for a legally binding ABS Protocol at COP 10 to address biopiracy, enforce fair benefit-sharing, and uphold indigenous rights, including free prior informed consent for traditional knowledge access. It urged the EU to lead global efforts by securing marine biodiversity protections, expanding terrestrial and marine protected areas, integrating biodiversity safeguards into climate policies (e.g., REDD+ reforms), and combating invasive species. The Parliament emphasized financing through market mechanisms (e.g., habitat banking, payment for ecosystem services), increased public and private funding, and corporate accountability. It advocated synergies among Rio Conventions, supported the IPBES platform for science-policy integration, and demanded biodiversity integration into trade agreements and MDGs. Specific measures included banning patents on life forms, establishing biofuel sustainability criteria, and reforming forest definitions to distinguish native ecosystems from monocultures. The resolution highlighted the need for transparent indicators, improved data tools like BISE, and equitable recognition of indigenous land rights in conservation strategies.

title: Motions for resolutions - EU action on oil exploration and extraction in Europe: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on EU action on oil exploration and extraction in Europe
background: The Deepwater Horizon oil spill in April 2010 highlighted risks of offshore drilling, coinciding with EU oil exploration activities in the North Sea and adjacent waters under existing environmental frameworks like the Habitats Directive and Marine Strategy Framework Directive. The Parliament will discuss enhancing safety standards and regulatory measures for offshore oil operations in EU territories.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the issue’s emphasis on stringent safety standards and cross-border spill response systems, aligning with their commitment to balanced environmental protection and energy security.  
EPP fully promotes expanding the European Maritime Safety Agency’s oversight mandate, a measure consistent with their 2023 priorities for integrated maritime governance.  
EPP proposes modifying the moratorium clause to explicitly link its duration to platform-specific safety certifications, ensuring energy diversification goals remain achievable.  
EPP applauds the issue’s focus on compulsory insurance mechanisms, which aligns with their market-based approach to environmental liability and risk management.  
EPP emphasizes accelerating revisions to the Environmental Liability Directive to address aging infrastructure risks, particularly in the North Sea, as highlighted in recent inspections.

EFD supports the issue’s safety objectives but proposes deleting paragraph 17 to avoid disproportionate restrictions on extraction industries.  
EFD advises revising paragraph 22 to ensure financial obligations on companies remain sustainable and competitiveness-preserving.  
EFD stresses the critical omission of research and development provisions, urging amendments to foster EU-US collaboration on extraction technology innovation.  
EFD endorses accident prevention measures but emphasizes that regulatory frameworks must balance environmental goals with industrial practicality.  
EFD cautions against blanket moratoriums, advocating instead for targeted safety upgrades to maintain energy security while mitigating risks.

ALDE strongly accepts the moratorium on new deep-sea drilling, aligning with ALDE's commitment to preventive environmental policy, while proposing a defined timeline for safety standard implementation to accelerate legislative urgency.  
ALDE strongly endorses the liability framework revisions, emphasizing that withholding new licenses until liability is codified creates essential economic incentives for corporate safety investments.  
ALDE strongly approves extending stringent EU safety standards to Arctic operations through binding third-country agreements, advancing ecological protection beyond EU borders as urged in the issue.  
ALDE strongly advocates for mandatory cross-border spill response systems in enclosed seas like the Mediterranean, recognizing their unique vulnerability as highlighted in Articles 4–6.  
ALDE strongly accepts rigorous accident prevention policies, including applying SEVESO II to offshore rigs, which directly aligns with ALDE's manifesto priorities for industrial safety reform.

SD strongly sanctions the issue’s call for unified EU-wide liability frameworks and compulsory insurance, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to holding polluters accountable and shielding taxpayers from disaster costs.  
SD approves the moratorium on new deep-sea drilling as a critical safeguard, proposing enhanced collaboration with clean energy sectors to ensure a just transition aligns with climate goals.  
SD endorses stringent cross-border safety standards and annual reporting, urging accelerated information-sharing protocols to address gaps in real-time spill monitoring highlighted by recent incidents.  
SD applauds the emphasis on extending SEVESO II and worker protections, which effectively advance SD’s manifesto priorities for industrial safety and labor rights in high-risk environments.  
SD proposes tightening harmonization of EIAs across all EU waters to eliminate regulatory disparities, ensuring no repeat of lax standards in ecologically sensitive regions like the Black Sea.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over offshore oil extraction risks following the Deepwater Horizon spill, urging immediate EU action to prevent similar disasters. It emphasized the need for stringent safety standards, cross-border spill response systems, and rigorous accident prevention policies, including extending the SEVESO II Directive to oil rigs and revising the Environmental Liability Directive to lower damage thresholds and cover marine waters. The resolution called for a moratorium on new deep-sea drilling in EU waters until safety standards are secured, stressed the Arctic’s ecological fragility, and highlighted risks in the North Sea, where fatal injury rates doubled. It demanded EU-wide liability frameworks, compulsory insurance or compensation funds for environmental damage, mandatory environmental impact assessments (EIAs) for all seabed activities, and enhanced transparency in corporate environmental practices. The Parliament urged the Commission to analyze the Gulf of Mexico’s environmental state, align third-country operations near EU borders with strict standards, and expand the European Maritime Safety Agency’s mandate to oversee offshore installations. Annual safety reports, improved worker protections, and decommissioning regulations for outdated infrastructure were also prioritized to safeguard biodiversity, coastal ecosystems, and EU energy security.

title: Information on medicinal products (Community code relating to medicinal products): REPORTon the proposal for adirectiveof the European Parliament and of the Councilamending, as regards information to the general public on medicinal products subject to medical prescription, Directive 2001/83/EC on the Community code relating to medicinal products for human use
background: Existing EU regulations on medicinal products permitted varying patient access to prescription drug information across member states, with disparities in availability, language accessibility, and concerns over distinguishing non-promotional information from advertising. The Parliament will discuss amendments to harmonize rules on pharmaceutical companies' provision of prescription medicine information to the public.

stances.stance:
EPP completely approves the issue's strict prohibition on advertising and patient-centered information channels, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to safeguarding public health through transparent, scientifically validated data.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the directive’s emphasis on empowering patients via pre-vetted, multilingual information sources, advancing EPP's priority to eliminate inequalities in healthcare access across the EU.  
EPP completely approves the ban on unsolicited promotional practices, reflecting EPP's unwavering stance against commercial inducements that risk excessive medicinal consumption.  
EPP applauds the issue’s reinforcement of physician-patient trust as the cornerstone of treatment decisions, consistent with EPP's advocacy for ethical healthcare frameworks.  
EPP perfectly aligns with provisions ensuring independent oversight of digital information, advancing EPP's manifesto goals to combat misleading content while promoting patient autonomy.

EFD rejects the issue's framework for failing to prevent pharmaceutical advertising disguised as information, contradicting their demand for strict separation.  
EFD opposes fundamentally the lack of binding mechanisms to enforce factual accuracy in drug data, which Anna Rosbach emphasized as critical for patient trust.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as mandatory standardization of product descriptions across borders, a gap Oreste Rossi highlighted as undermining comparative safety assessments.

This firmly rejects with EFD's position that patient organizations—not pharmaceutical firms—should lead non-promotional communications, as noted in Rossi's call for citizen-representative oversight.

ECR fundamentally promotes the issue's prohibition of direct-to-consumer advertising for prescription medicines, aligning perfectly with ECR's commitment to patient autonomy through voluntary information access.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the emphasis on national healthcare authorities as primary information sources, effectively advancing ECR's priority of transparent, state-anchored health governance.  
ECR applauds the recognition of electronic information channels, reinforcing ECR's longstanding advocacy for digital accessibility in patient empowerment.  
ECR strongly advocates the ban on inducements for excessive medicinal use, mirroring ECR's manifesto principles against market-driven healthcare distortions.  
ECR endorses the issue's globalized approach to information sharing, preventing European patients from relying on non-EU sources as warned by ECR members.

GUE_NGL totally conflicts any provisions allowing pharmaceutical companies to influence public information channels, as seen in the rejected Fjellner amendment.

GUE_NGL rejects mechanisms that shift responsibility from manufacturers, demanding explicit accountability clauses omitted in current drafts.  
The issue's tolerance of industry-backed amendments undermines transparency principles central to GUE_NGL's health policy agenda.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the regulation of medicinal product promotion, adopting a position at first reading based on the Commission’s 2008 proposal (COM(2008)0663) and aligning with Treaty provisions, notably Article 114 and Article 168(4)(c) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU. It instructed the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments to the original text and directed its President to communicate the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reflecting procedural adherence under relevant Treaty frameworks and stakeholder consultations, including the European Economic and Social Committee’s 2009 opinion.

title: Information on medicinal products (Community procedures for the authorisation and supervision of medicinal products): REPORTon the proposal for aregulationof the European Parliament and of the Council onamending, as regards information to the general public on medicinal products for human use subject to medical prescription, Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 laying down Community procedures for the authorisation and supervision of medicinal products for human and veterinary use and establishing a European Medicines Agency
background: Existing EU regulations on medicinal product authorization lacked harmonized rules for public information on prescription drugs, leading to disparities in patient access across member states and concerns over potential advertising. The Parliament will discuss amending procedures to regulate information dissemination while balancing patient rights and preventing promotional content.

stances.stance:
EPP totally sanctions the issue's strict ban on advertising while ensuring patient-centric access to scientifically validated information through multiple controlled channels, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to healthcare transparency.  
EPP perfectly aligns with provisions requiring national authorities to pre-vet medicinal product information, reinforcing EPP's principle of safeguarding patients from misleading commercial influences.  
EPP fully supports harmonizing multilingual information standards across the EU to eliminate healthcare inequalities, advancing EPP's priority of pan-European public health equity.  
EPP endorses the issue's emphasis on physician-patient trust as the primary information channel, consistent with EPP's longstanding advocacy for doctor-led healthcare decision-making.  
EPP strongly approves mandatory reliability certifications for online medicinal content, effectively advancing consumer protection goals outlined in EPP's digital single market agenda.

ECR firmly endorses the issue's mandate for patient-led health autonomy through unrestricted access to verified medicinal information, aligning perfectly with ECR's longstanding commitment to individual sovereignty in healthcare decision-making.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the prohibition of direct pharmaceutical advertising to consumers, recognizing this as a critical safeguard against commercial influence over prescription medicine awareness.  
ECR firmly endorses the prioritization of national health authorities and medical professionals as primary information sources, which effectively advances ECR's priority of maintaining rigorous, state-anchored healthcare governance.  
ECR applauds the directive’s modernization of information delivery formats, including electronic accessibility, as a strategic response to globalized digital health literacy demands consistent with ECR’s 21st-century policy frameworks.  
ECR unequivocally supports the issue’s alignment with Treaty provisions on institutional collaboration, reinforcing procedural transparency as a cornerstone of EU legislative integrity.

GUE_NGL rejects the inclusion of commercial campaigns by pharmaceutical companies, which contradict their stance against corporate influence in public health information.  
GUE_NGL opposes any amendments that reintroduce rejected provisions, such as print media channels, deeming them inconsistent with patient-centered transparency.  
The proposal completely disapproves with GUE_NGL's principle of holding companies fully accountable for the information they disseminate to patients.  
GUE_NGL criticizes attempts to weaken the issue's safeguards, viewing them as retrograde steps that undermine consumer protection.  
The issue's failure to explicitly prohibit industry-driven information channels overlooks critical patient rights to unbiased medical data.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a Commission proposal (COM(2008)0662) related to interinstitutional decision-making procedures following the Treaty of Lisbon’s implementation, emphasizing adherence to relevant treaty provisions, including Article 294(3), Article 114, and Article 168(4)(c) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU. It adopted its first-reading stance (A7‑0289/2010) based on reports from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, alongside opinions from the Committees on Industry, Research and Energy, and the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. The resolution called on the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantial amendments or a replacement text are planned, ensuring parliamentary oversight. It further instructed its President to formally communicate Parliament’s position to the Council, the Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural transparency and institutional collaboration.

title: Honey: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Directive 2001/110/EC relating to honey
background: In 2009, the European Court of Justice ruled pollen in honey as an ingredient under EU law, conflicting with beekeepers' practices and international standards. The European Commission proposed amending Directive 2001/110/EC in 2012 to address legal uncertainties. The Parliament will discuss clarifying pollen's classification as a natural constituent or ingredient in honey.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA fundamentally againsts the issue's failure to mandate GMO pollen labeling, directly contradicting their commitment to strict GMO transparency in food products.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the proposal's omission of binding coexistence policies for GMO crops and apiaries, which ignores bees' 10-14 km foraging range and risks environmental contamination.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's inconsistency with EU Court of Justice rulings that classify GMO pollen as non-natural ingredients requiring risk assessment and authorization.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the disregard for existing national practices like Germany's GMO-free certification, proving feasible market solutions without economic disruption.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the artificial separation of "natural" and GMO pollen in regulatory frameworks, violating their principle that all genetically modified components demand rigorous oversight.

ALDE supports confirming pollen as a natural component of honey under Directive 2001/110/EC, aligning with biological realities rather than artificial ingredient classification.  
ALDE advises maintaining the 0.9% GMO threshold for honey while proposing broader transparency measures for genetically modified materials across all food sectors.  
ALDE emphasizes protecting small-scale beekeeping viability by avoiding disproportionate labeling requirements that mislead consumers about honey’s inherent properties.  
ALDE recommends amending Annex I to explicitly define pollen as a “constituent” rather than “ingredient,” mirroring natural production processes described in the debate.  
ALDE urges reinforcing alignment with EFSA’s scientific assessments to prevent litigation risks while ensuring consumer trust in honey’s authenticity.

ECR advises prioritizing GMO crop restrictions over honey labeling mandates, aligning with Committee on Agriculture recommendations to address contamination at its source.  
ECR endorses streamlining EU honey market access by adopting the Commission’s proposal on compositional standards, consistent with Treaty Article 43(2) alignment goals.  
ECR proposes rejecting ENVI Committee amendments requiring additive disclosures, as these risk consumer confusion contrary to issue clarity objectives.  
ECR highlights member state sovereignty in agricultural policy, urging adherence to national GMO opt-outs referenced in the 2012 Commission opinion.

GUE_NGL rejects the proposal's failure to address systemic GMO contamination risks in honey production, entirely againsting with their opposition to large-scale transgenic crop cultivation.  
GUE_NGL opposes permitting undisclosed GMO pollen in honey as inconsistent with their demand for full consumer transparency on genetic modifications.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's oversight of root causes, overlooking critical aspects like banning open-air GMO cultivation to prevent environmental cross-contamination.  
GUE_NGL condemns the procedural focus on labeling thresholds instead of prohibiting GMO-derived pollen, contradicting their 2013 amendments seeking strict "zero tolerance" policies.  
GUE_NGL insists any solution must challenge EU agro-industrial policies enabling GMO proliferation, which this directive amendment fails to initiate.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s 2012 proposal (COM(2012)0530), emphasizing procedural alignment with Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union Articles 43(2) and 294, and incorporating input from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report (A7-0440/2013) and the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development’s opinion. It formally adopted its stance, urged the Commission to resubmit the matter if proposing substantial amendments or alternative texts, and directed its President to transmit Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring adherence to legislative protocols under Rule 55 of its Rules of Procedure and the European Economic and Social Committee’s 2012 opinion.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2013 proposal (COM(2013)0761) concerning legislative measures under Article 114 of the TFEU, adopting its first-reading stance as outlined in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report (A7-0174/2014). title: Motions for resolutions - Tuberculosis Vaccine Initiative: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the Tuberculosis Vaccine Initiative (TBVI) – practical implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy with a view to meeting MDG 6 and eliminating tuberculosis by 2050
background: Persistent global tuberculosis incidence, drug-resistant strains, and the EU's €2 billion annual treatment costs underpin efforts to meet UN Millennium Development Goal 6 (halt TB by 2015) and WHO eradication targets. The Parliament will discuss integrating the Tuberculosis Vaccine Initiative into Europe 2020 research strategies to address these objectives.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the integration of TBVI into the Europe 2020 strategy, aligning with their commitment to advancing global health equity through targeted research and innovation.

EPP proposes enhancing the issue by explicitly mandating support for healthcare worker retention in developing countries, addressing systemic staffing shortages that exacerbate treatment gaps.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the global tuberculosis (TB) epidemic, noting its status as a leading cause of death with nearly 2 million annual fatalities, exacerbated by drug-resistant strains and inequalities in healthcare access. It emphasized the urgent need for vaccines, improved diagnostics, and affordable treatments, aligning with the WHO’s goal to halve TB prevalence and mortality by 2015 and eliminate the disease by 2050. The resolution highlighted the Tuberculosis Vaccine Initiative (TBVI) as critical for accelerating vaccine development and urged the EU to integrate TBVI into the Europe 2020 strategy, leveraging innovative funding mechanisms like European Investment Bank guarantees to support research for neglected diseases. It stressed the importance of increasing sustainable R&D investments, including the 3% GDP target, and addressing systemic healthcare gaps in developing countries, where structural underfunding and lack of infrastructure worsen outcomes. The Parliament called for a holistic approach combining disease-specific programs with strengthened public health systems, prioritizing free healthcare access, clean water, nutrition, and equitable distribution of EU-funded resources to impoverished regions. It underscored the interconnectedness of TB with HIV/AIDS and global inequality, urging the Commission and Member States to uphold funding commitments and ensure healthcare reaches marginalized populations, particularly in remote areas.

ECR endorses harmonized market rules under Article 114 while suggesting refining Amendment 61’s substitution criteria to explicitly exempt rotation-dependent active substances.  
ECR applauds the issue’s rejection of non-scientific bans on critical biocides, aligning with their commitment to practical pest control solutions for agricultural stakeholders.  
ECR advocates retaining Annex VII provisions for rodenticide rotation systems, proposing strengthened labeling requirements to enhance user compliance.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's market-first approach as fundamentally disapproveing with their mandate to prioritize human health and environmental protection over free circulation of biocides.  
GUE_NGL opposes the proposal's failure to institute a strict ban on carcinogenic and non-biodegradable biocides, directly contradicting their demand for hazard elimination in Amendment 352.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's oversight of 400,000 tonnes/year household biocide risks as incompatible with their child safety advocacy, particularly regarding wood preservatives and insect sprays.  
GUE_NGL condemns the text's reliance on manufacturer assurances of "proper use," which neglects real-world accident scenarios central to their consumer protection principles.  
GUE_NGL demands rejection of the Commission's framework for enabling hazardous substance circulation, insisting on binding toxicity thresholds absent in the current Articles.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s 2009 proposal (COM(2009)0267), emphasizing the need to align the legislative process with the Treaty of Lisbon’s provisions, particularly Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU, to ensure harmonization of internal market rules. It called on the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments or alternative texts, safeguarding procedural integrity under Article 294(3). The resolution integrated opinions from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, and the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (A7-0239/2010), reflecting cross-committee consensus. Parliament instructed its President to transmit its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing transparency and interinstitutional accountability.

title: Sulphur content of marine fuels: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 1999/32/EC as regards the sulphur content of marine fuels
background: The International Maritime Organisation’s 2008 agreement established stricter sulphur limits for marine fuels to reduce air pollution, prompting the EU to update its 1999 directive. Regional disparities in existing standards and compliance timelines necessitated legislative action. The Parliament will discuss aligning EU regulations with international norms and addressing environmental and public health implications of maritime emissions.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the issue's alignment with global sulphur standards, emphasizing its critical role in curbing maritime emissions that threaten public health and environmental progress.  
EPP applauds the balanced regional differentiation approach, recognizing objective health imperatives in the Baltic and North Sea while upholding the International Maritime Organisation's framework as consistent with EPP's environmental-economic synergy principles.  
EPP proposes future harmonization of sulphur limits across all EU waters to address equity concerns, framing current asymmetries as transitional necessities pending broader fuel availability and port infrastructure upgrades.  
EPP endorses the 2020 implementation timeline and MARPOL revision clause, highlighting their congruence with EPP's manifesto priorities for sustainable transport investment cycles and regulatory predictability.  
EPP urges accelerated development of LNG infrastructure and scrubber technologies to mitigate sectoral disruptions, reinforcing the issue's focus on long-term competitiveness alongside emission reductions.

EFD rejects the directive's disproportionate sulphur limits as firmly challengeing with their commitment to fair internal market competition.  
EFD opposes the Baltic Sea's fivefold stricter regulation compared to Mediterranean zones, citing severe economic harm to Finnish export industries.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of regional economic dependency, risking 20 000 job losses and €500 million annual costs in Finland.  
EFD condemns the issue's distortion of market fairness, evidenced by UPM's production relocation threat due to uncompetitive operational burdens.  
This approach is inconsistent with EFD's principle of balanced environmental regulation respecting Member States' economic realities.

GREEN_EFA strongly endorses the issue’s stringent sulphur limits as a critical step to mitigate maritime pollution, aligning perfectly with their commitment to safeguarding marine ecosystems and public health.  
GREEN_EFA approves the Baltic Sea’s enhanced protections, recognizing its ecological sensitivity and the necessity for region-specific measures to preserve brackish water biodiversity.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the cost feasibility of scrubber investments, rebutting industry exaggerations by emphasizing minimal financial impacts relative to long-term environmental and human health gains.  
GREEN_EFA endorses harmonizing shipping emissions with land-based transport standards, advancing a level playing field that prioritizes air quality equity across transport sectors.  
GREEN_EFA counters opposition claims about regional competition, asserting that differentiated rules for sensitive areas do not undermine trade but align with science-driven environmental stewardship.

ALDE strongly advocates the issue’s harmonization of sulphur limits with IMO standards, aligning perfectly with their commitment to environmentally effective maritime policy while upholding international obligations.  
ALDE applauds the balanced approach to emission reductions in SECA zones, advancing cleaner air through market-compatible mechanisms as outlined in their sustainability priorities.  
ALDE proposes enhanced post-2015 monitoring of modal shift risks and regional competitiveness impacts to ensure the policy’s ecological goals do not inadvertently disadvantage northern maritime economies.  
ALDE endorses the cross-committee collaboration reflected in the issue, reinforcing their principle of evidence-based policymaking for complex environmental challenges.  
ALDE emphasizes the need for future reviews to address transitional disparities between SECA and Mediterranean regions, ensuring equitable implementation without opposing the core standards.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0439) concerning environmental and transport policies under Article 192(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, adopting its first-reading stance as outlined in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report (A7-0038/2012) and incorporating input from the Committee on Transport and Tourism. It emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant amendments or alternative texts to ensure alignment with legislative intent. The resolution further instructed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural transparency and inter-institutional accountability.

title: Sound level of motor vehicles: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the sound level of motor vehicles
background: Persistent public health concerns over traffic noise exposure linked to cardiovascular risks by WHO studies, coupled with outdated EU vehicle noise standards last revised in 1995, prompted legislative review. The Parliament will discuss updated motor vehicle noise regulations to address health impacts and align technical standards with current environmental and public health priorities.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the issue's phased decibel reduction framework, aligning with EPP's commitment to balanced environmental progress without jeopardizing industrial stability during economic recovery.  
EPP proposes revising Annex III classification thresholds through technical expert consultation to better reflect UNECE standards and current automotive engineering realities.
