EPP endorses mandatory acoustic vehicle alert systems for electric/hybrid vehicles as a safety imperative, ensuring pedestrian protection complements noise reduction objectives.  
EPP advocates expanding the noise reduction strategy to include road surface quality standards and tire innovation incentives, creating a holistic approach beyond engine-focused metrics.  
EPP recommends adopting Amendment 61's extended implementation timeline to maintain emission reduction ambition while allowing manufacturers transitional flexibility for compliance.

GREEN_EFA totally rejects with the issue's diluted noise reduction targets, which fail to address the €54 billion annual health cost burden from traffic noise highlighted in their 2023 policy briefs.  
GREEN_EFA rejects Amendment 61's loopholes allowing phased compliance timelines, directly contradicting their demand for immediate "quiet vehicle" mandates in urban zones.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the false industry collapse narrative, emphasizing their Automotive Innovation Fund proposal (2021/C 301/08) demonstrates feasible electrification pathways.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's inconsistency with WHO night noise guidelines (Lnight <45 dB), permitting 20% higher thresholds than medically advised.  
GREEN_EFA demands binding measures to eliminate combustion engine idling noise by 2028, absent from current Article 4 provisions.

ALDE strongly accepts the issue’s focus on harmonized noise testing standards, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s commitment to innovation-driven market efficiency and cross-border regulatory coherence.  
ALDE proposes amending Annex II to introduce three power-based categories for heavy vehicles (below 180 kW, 180–250 kW, above 250 kW), ensuring tailored noise limits that reflect operational diversity without compromising reduction targets.  
ALDE approves the ENVI Committee’s balanced approach to industry collaboration, which advances Europe’s automotive competitiveness while addressing noise pollution through technological leadership.  
ALDE recommends extending the implementation timeline in Article 7 to 2030 for certain vehicle classes, allowing manufacturers adequate transition periods to meet stricter acoustic requirements.  
ALDE emphasizes that standardized measurement protocols under Amendment 12 will strengthen the internal market by eliminating technical barriers to trade, a core priority in ALDE’s economic agenda.

GUE_NGL rejects the proposal's failure to counteract automotive lobbyist influence undermining public health protections.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the delayed 7-year implementation timeline as incompatible with urgent noise pollution mitigation needs.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's omission of binding mechanisms to hold manufacturers financially accountable for noise-related societal costs.  
GUE_NGL highlights the proposal's disregard for WHO health impact studies, conflicting with GUE_NGL's mandate to prioritize environmental justice.  
GUE_NGL asserts the text institutionalizes corporate cost externalization, violating the polluter-pays principle central to their policy framework.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal (COM(2011)0856) concerning EU internal market measures under Article 114 TFEU, adopting its first-reading stance as outlined in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report (A7-0435/2012). It emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments or replacements to the proposal arise, ensuring legislative coherence and procedural accountability. The resolution further instructed the Parliament’s President to formally transmit its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing inter-institutional communication and alignment in the legislative process.

title: Standards of quality and safety of human organs intended for transplantation: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on standards of quality and safety of human organs intended for transplantation
background: Significant disparities in organ donation rates among EU member states and persistent shortages affecting over 56,000 patients awaiting transplants necessitated harmonized quality and safety protocols. The Parliament will discuss establishing EU-wide standards for human organ transplantation to address cross-border compatibility and improve healthcare outcomes.

stances.stance:
EPP totally agrees the Spanish model of transplant coordination as a blueprint for EU-wide efficiency gains in organ donation systems  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's binding provisions ensuring voluntary unpaid donations while combating organ trafficking through traceability measures  
EPP fully supports cross-border organ exchange protocols enabled by harmonized quality standards to address critical patient waiting lists  
EPP strongly advocates maintaining professional hospital transplant coordinators as essential to replicating Spain's 34.4 donors/million success EU-wide  
EPP unequivocally backs the directive's balance between data protection requirements and clinical traceability needs to prevent illegal organ trade

EFD supports the issue’s emphasis on EU-level coordination to harmonize divergent national regulations, aligning with EFD’s call to eliminate disparities in donor consent frameworks and insurance schemes.  
EFD advises amending Article 4 to mandate standardized health screening protocols for all organs, addressing concerns about contagious diseases and ensuring donor-recipient safety.  
EFD endorses the introduction of a European donor card and stricter penalties for illegal trafficking, as proposed in the debate, to combat transplant tourism and organ commercialization.  
EFD recommends reinforcing provisions for non-commercial living donations, ensuring compensation is strictly limited to post-operation inconveniences as defined by national laws.  
EFD highlights the need to prioritize post-mortem donations over living donations in Directive Annex II, minimizing risks of coercion while maintaining altruistic donation principles.

ALDE totally agrees the directive’s focus on increasing organ donations through awareness campaigns and dismantling administrative barriers, perfectly aligning with ALDE’s commitment to patient-centered healthcare innovation.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s mandate for national quality-control authorities, emphasizing transparency and safety from donor extraction to transplantation as critical to harmonizing EU standards.  
ALDE highlights the Basque Country’s record donation rates as proof that regional coordination systems and public awareness, as promoted in the directive, effectively advance cross-border health collaboration.  
ALDE fully supports the authorization of non-optimal organ use in emergencies and expanded living donations, reflecting ALDE’s prioritization of pragmatic, life-saving solutions within ethical frameworks.  
ALDE applauds the inclusion of digital donor registries and identity markers as transformative tools to accelerate donations, reinforcing ALDE’s vision for technology-driven healthcare efficiency.

SD totally upholds the issue's absolute prohibition of organ commercialization, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to ethical voluntary donation systems that eliminate profit motives.  
SD perfectly supports harmonizing EU-wide donor identification protocols to replicate Spain's success in achieving 40 donations per million citizens through optimized consent frameworks.  
SD unequivocally backs the mandate for traceable transnational organ exchanges, recognizing this as critical to reducing daily patient deaths through coordinated cross-border availability.  
SD champions the issue's reinforcement of post-transplant monitoring standards as essential for maintaining public trust in donation systems across all Member States.  
SD fully aligns with the directive's requirement for national authorities to combat transplant tourism, ensuring European patients never face incentives to seek illegal procedures abroad.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its adoption of the position at first reading on the Commission’s 2008 proposal (COM(2008)0818) concerning public health measures under Article 152(4)(a) of the EC Treaty and Article 168(4) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU, as outlined in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report (A7‑0106/2009). It emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if intending to substantially amend or replace the proposal, ensuring legislative continuity and transparency. The resolution further mandated the Parliament’s President to formally transmit its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural adherence under Rule 55 of its Rules of Procedure while focusing on substantive health policy alignment.

title: Portable batteries and accumulators containing cadmium: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2006/66/EC on batteries and accumulators and waste batteries and accumulators as regards the placing on the market of portable batteries and accumulators containing cadmium intended for use in cordless power tools
background: The 2006 EU Batteries Directive restricted hazardous substances but permitted exemptions, including cadmium in cordless power tool batteries, amid concerns over environmental contamination and health risks from improper disposal. The Parliament will discuss amending the directive to address cadmium use exemptions and associated regulatory harmonization in battery manufacturing.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the ban on cadmium in cordless power tool batteries, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to environmental protection and public health prioritization.  
EPP approves the transitional period for industry adaptation, effectively advancing EPP's priority of maintaining EU competitiveness while ensuring safe technological transitions for SMEs.  
EPP endorses the removal of button cell exemptions, recognizing this as a critical enhancement to child safety and pollution prevention in line with circular economy principles.  
EPP proposes strengthening consumer awareness campaigns about battery recycling protocols to maximize the directive's environmental impact without opposing its core provisions.  
EPP applauds the issue's coherence with previous regulatory successes against heavy metals, reinforcing EPP's evidence-based approach to hazardous substance management.

EFD supports the environmental protection goals but advises amending Article 4 to extend the cadmium battery phase-out deadline to 2016, allowing transitional flexibility for cost-sensitive markets.  
EFD highlights economic disparities by proposing a recital emphasizing affordability mechanisms for lithium alternatives in lower-income EU regions.  
EFD concurs with recycling system enhancements but stresses amended Annex II should mandate member state subsidies for SME battery replacement programs.  
EFD acknowledges cadmium toxicity concerns while urging consideration of amended exemption clauses for professional-grade power tools lacking viable alternatives.  
EFD aligns with stakeholder consultation principles but requests Article 9 revisions requiring biennial reviews of battery technology accessibility metrics.

GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the total ban on cadmium in portable batteries, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to eliminating toxic substances and advancing circular economy principles.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the expedited phase-out of exemptions for cordless power tools by 2016, effectively addressing past lobbying-driven loopholes and prioritizing public health.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the mandatory replaceability of batteries as a critical step to reduce e-waste, ensuring consumer affordability and market competition in line with their 2023 sustainability manifesto.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amending Annex II to include explicit capacity labeling requirements for single-use batteries, enhancing transparency and fulfilling the Commission’s unmet 2009 commitment.  
GREEN_EFA approves the reinforced inter-institutional transparency measures, particularly Parliament’s oversight role in delegated acts, which safeguard against diluted environmental standards.

SD strongly endorses the prohibition of cadmium in portable batteries, aligning with their commitment to environmental protection and public health, as highlighted by the successful reduction of toxic substances in household products.  
SD applauds the promotion of innovative, eco-friendly technologies in cordless power tools, which effectively advances sustainability goals and minimizes environmental pollution risks.  
SD endorses the enhanced product design requirements that facilitate easy battery replacement, addressing resource waste and fostering a circular economy as emphasized in the issue.  
SD highlights the importance of strict enforcement mechanisms for battery collection and recycling to ensure compliance with environmental safety standards, proposing periodic reviews of delegated acts for technical adaptability.  
SD commends the collaborative institutional efforts that prioritize health protections from hazardous metals, reinforcing the necessity of professional legislative processes to achieve tangible public health outcomes.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position by adopting the resolution at first reading, which centers on legislative procedures under Articles 192(1) and 114(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, addressing environmental and internal market harmonization objectives. It endorsed the Commission’s 2012 proposal (COM(2012)0136) while emphasizing the need for delegated acts to ensure flexibility in implementing technical updates. The resolution instructs the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments or replacements to the proposal are planned, safeguarding legislative oversight. It further directed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing inter-institutional transparency and procedural adherence. The resolution integrates input from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (A7-0131/2013) and aligns with the European Economic and Social Committee’s 2012 opinion, prioritizing legal coherence and stakeholder consultation.

title: Possibility for Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMOs in their territory: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2001/18/EC as regards the possibility for the Member States to restrict or prohibit the cultivation of GMOs in their territory
background: The EU's existing regulatory framework allowed centralized GMO authorization but faced challenges as member states increasingly invoked safeguard clauses to restrict cultivation, conflicting with single market principles and prompting legal disputes. The Parliament will discuss amending GMO cultivation rules to reconcile national autonomy with EU-wide authorization processes.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA firmly promotes the issue's establishment of liability frameworks ensuring polluters bear costs for GMO contamination, perfectly aligning with their principle of ecological accountability.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's recognition of socio-economic impacts and biodiversity preservation as valid grounds for national GMO bans, advancing their vision of farmer sovereignty.  
GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the rejection of GMO cultivation as a solution to global hunger, affirming their commitment to agroecological systems over industrial monocultures.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue's reinforcement of coexistence rules between GMO and non-GMO agriculture, safeguarding consumer choice and organic farming integrity.  
GREEN_EFA recognizes the issue's critical improvement over the Commission’s flawed proposal by creating a legally robust pathway for Member States to restrict GMOs.

ALDE strongly upholds the establishment of a common European framework enabling Member States to restrict GMO cultivation, aligning with their commitment to subsidiarity in environmental protection.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s harmonization of legal frameworks under Article 114 TFEU, ensuring procedural clarity while respecting regional biodiversity priorities.  
ALDE proposes reinforcing internal market coherence in future reviews by requiring EFSA’s risk assessments to inform national restrictions, addressing concerns about precedent-setting without opposing the core provision.  
ALDE emphasizes that safeguarding public health and environmental integrity must supersede unqualified market freedoms, as articulated in their 2023 sustainability agenda.  
ALDE urges strict adherence to transparency mechanisms in transmitting issues to national parliaments, ensuring citizen-centric governance.

SD strongly agrees the issue's empowerment of Member States to restrict GMO cultivation, aligning with SD's commitment to environmental precaution and subsidiarity in agricultural policy.  
SD approves the inclusion of socio-economic and environmental grounds for prohibitions, enhancing legal certainty as emphasized in multiple committee inputs.  
SD highlights the need to amend Article 4 to mandate EU-funded research on long-term GMO impacts, addressing concerns raised about unresolved ecological risks.  
SD endorses the issue’s respect for public skepticism, strongly mirroring Eurobarometer findings and SD’s prioritization of citizen-led policymaking.  
SD proposes strengthening coexistence protocols by specifying minimum buffer zones between GMO/conventional crops to operationalize Jo Leinen’s call for farmer choice safeguards.

ECR fundamentally rejects the issue’s framework for GMO restrictions, arguing it exceeds the Commission’s original proposal and entrenches anti-GMO bias contrary to scientific validation processes.  
ECR rejects the report’s emphasis on non-scientific grounds for Member State prohibitions, viewing this as a direct contradiction to EFSA’s authority and internal market harmonization principles.  
ECR opposes the issue’s failure to liberalize cultivation rights for EFSA-approved GMOs, which undermines farmer competitiveness in global markets.  
ECR conflicts with the proposal’s neglect of alternative techniques like cisgenesis, demanding explicit recognition to align with innovation-friendly agricultural policies.  
 While some ECR members acknowledge Member State sovereignty provisions, the group maintains unified opposition to the issue’s restrictive core.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2010 proposal (COM(2010)0375) to harmonize internal market rules under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), adopting its first-reading stance based on the Committee on Environment, Public Health, and Food Safety’s report and incorporating input from the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. It emphasized the need for alignment with legal and procedural frameworks, including opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions. The resolution affirmed Parliament’s formal adoption of its negotiated position, urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal if intending substantial amendments, and instructed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to ensure procedural continuity and transparency.

title: Priority substances in the field of water policy: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directives 2000/60/EC and 2008/105/EC as regards priority substances in the field of water policy
background: The European Union’s Water Framework Directive (2000/60/EC) and Environmental Quality Standards Directive (2008/105/EC) established chemical quality norms for surface waters, with ongoing reviews identifying additional pollutants requiring regulation due to persistence, toxicity, and bioaccumulation risks. The Parliament will discuss amendments to update priority substance lists for enhanced water quality management.

stances.stance:
EPP fundamentally endorses the watchlist mechanism for monitoring pharmaceutical substances, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to proactive environmental stewardship.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on continuous updates to priority substance lists, advancing EPP's priority of safeguarding water quality through adaptive governance.  
EPP fully supports the trilogue compromise as a critical step toward water security, reflecting EPP's dedication to collaborative, science-driven policymaking in environmental protection.  
EPP endorses the integration of citizen concerns about water purity into legislative action, consistent with EPP's principle of prioritizing public health and ecological resilience.  
EPP applauds the issue's balanced approach to emerging contaminants, perfectly aligning with EPP's manifesto goals for sustainable water resource management.

ALDE strongly advocates the issue's evidence-based approach to pharmaceutical substances, aligning with their commitment to proportionate regulation that balances environmental protection with healthcare accessibility.  
ALDE approves the downgrading of pharmaceuticals to the watch list, preventing undue restrictions on vital medications like contraceptives while maintaining water quality monitoring frameworks.  
ALDE emphasizes the necessity of cost-benefit rigor in environmental policy, welcoming the alignment with WHO risk assessments to avoid scientifically unsubstantiated regulatory burdens.  
ALDE highlights the importance of safeguarding medication availability as a core public health priority, endorsing the compromise that rejects blanket priority listing without proven ecological harm.  
ALDE proposes periodic review mechanisms for the watch list as an enhancement opportunity, ensuring future updates reflect emerging research without opposing the current framework.

SD absolutely upholds the inclusion of pharmaceuticals in the EU-wide monitoring watchlist, ensuring public transparency on concentrations and laying the groundwork for future regulatory action, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to proactive environmental health safeguards.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s mandate for stricter threshold limits on substances already classified as hazardous, emphasizing the urgency of accelerating implementation timelines to prevent prolonged ecological risks.  
SD fully supports the expansion of synergies between water quality frameworks and REACH/pesticide legislation, reinforcing a holistic approach to pollution control as demanded by SD’s environmental policy priorities.  
SD endorses the issue’s emphasis on EU-level regulatory coherence for transboundary water systems, directly addressing cross-border contamination risks and safeguarding vulnerable communities from arsenic and nitrate-related health crises.  
SD acknowledges the watchlist mechanism as a critical interim step for monitoring endocrine-disrupting pharmaceuticals, aligning with Eurobarometer findings on public demand for robust water quality protections against emerging pollutants.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's implicit tolerance of water service privatization pressures, absolutely condemning with their principle of water as an inalienable public good.  
GUE_NGL opposes the proposal's failure to mandate robust public monitoring systems, overlooking critical aspects of water quality protection outlined in their 2012 manifesto.  
GUE_NGL condemns the Commission's contradictory approach that weakens state capacity while claiming environmental protection, directly violating Article 9 of the EU Water Framework Directive.  
GUE_NGL denounces the issue's alignment with austerity-driven service cuts in Portugal, inconsistent with maintaining essential public water infrastructure.  
GUE_NGL challenges the legislative process for enabling Commission interference in national water governance, demanding explicit bans on privatization mandates.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0876) by adopting its stance at first reading, as outlined in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report (A7-0397/2012). It called on the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantial amendments or a replacement text are planned, ensuring parliamentary oversight. The Parliament also instructed its President to formally transmit its adopted position to the Council, the Commission, and national parliaments, aligning with procedural requirements under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and its Rules of Procedure. The resolution incorporated input from the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions, emphasizing collaborative decision-making while focusing on the substantive adoption of its legislative position.

title: Programme for the environment and climate action (LIFE): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the establishment of a Programme for the Environment and Climate Action (LIFE)
background: The EU’s LIFE Programme, operational since 1992, faced renewal under the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework amid evolving environmental priorities and funding challenges. The Parliament will discuss establishing a revised Programme for Environment and Climate Action to address biodiversity, climate change, and policy implementation.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the LIFE Programme's budget expansion and climate action tripling, aligning perfectly with their commitment to cross-border environmental innovation and Natura 2000 preservation.  
EPP approves enhanced co-financing structures enabling member states to maximize project scalability while safeguarding national implementation frameworks critical for regional biodiversity.  
EPP proposes streamlining VAT reimbursement processes and personnel cost eligibility to broaden SME participation, enhancing grassroots environmental entrepreneurship without compromising core funding streams.  
EPP emphasizes integrating agricultural sustainability measures through coordinated LIFE-CAP synergies, advancing both ecological targets and rural economic stability as championed in their climate manifestos.  
EPP advocates periodic impact assessments of integrated projects to optimize job creation metrics, ensuring LIFE's economic benefits match its ecological ambitions through evidence-based refinements.

ALDE strongly agrees the issue's emphasis on maintaining LIFE Programme funding quality, aligning with their commitment to effective EU environmental instruments.  
ALDE applauds the proposed 10% budget allocation for Natura 2000 as critical to addressing biodiversity gaps, reflecting their prioritization of measurable conservation targets.  
ALDE urges the Commission to conduct an annual analysis of nature conservation spending across EU funds to ensure alignment with Biodiversity Strategy goals, enhancing accountability.  
ALDE endorses safeguarding LIFE's traditional project funding while expanding innovative instruments, preventing resource diversion from proven environmental initiatives.  
ALDE emphasizes rejecting Member States' attempts to lower co-financing standards, insisting on quality-driven allocations over purely national quota systems.

SD strongly agrees the issue’s emphasis on biodiversity protection and Natura 2000 funding, aligning perfectly with SD’s longstanding commitment to halting irreversible environmental degradation. The proposed 10% allocation to Natura 2000 directly advances SD’s priority of bridging critical funding gaps through LIFE’s proven mechanisms.  

SD applauds the focus on capacity-building in underutilized regions and higher co-financing rates for less-developed areas, which effectively addresses regional disparities in environmental investment and ensures equitable implementation of EU climate laws.  

SD endorses the integration of climate action across EU policies via LIFE projects, noting that this approach mirrors SD’s advocacy for cross-sectoral sustainability and green job creation as outlined in the EU2020 strategy.  

SD proposes enhancing future Multiannual Financial Framework negotiations to progressively increase LIFE’s budget beyond current proposals, ensuring full alignment with the Treaty of Lisbon’s environmental obligations while maintaining support for traditional projects.  

SD highlights the necessity of safeguarding LIFE’s core environmental sub-programs, emphasizing that expanding the program’s scope must not compromise funding for high-impact initiatives like habitat restoration or anti-biodiversity loss measures.

GUE/NGL fundamentally doubts the proposed LIFE Programme budget as it fails to allocate the demanded 1% of the EU budget, perpetuating systemic underfunding of environmental priorities central to their platform.  
GUE/NGL rejects the reliance on co-financing mechanisms and private sources, which they argue creates unequal access for smaller projects and contradicts their principle of equitable EU-led environmental stewardship.  
The proposal overlooks critical structural barriers identified by GUE/NGL, including insufficient technical support for proposal drafting and regional disparities in project approval rates, which undermine participatory environmental governance.  
GUE/NGL warns that expanding LIFE’s climate scope without binding safeguards risks deprioritizing biodiversity conservation, directly conflicting with their demand to maintain Natura 2000 as the program’s core mission.  
The issue’s 10% allocation for Natura 2000 is deemed grossly inadequate by GUE/NGL, who insist this represents a retreat from binding Treaty obligations rather than meaningful progress.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the adequacy of the proposed financial envelope for the LIFE Programme (2014-2020), emphasizing that its final budget depends on the ongoing Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) negotiations. It stressed the need for increased resources to meet EU priorities, including the EU2020 strategy and Treaty of Lisbon obligations, noting that even a 5% budget increase over 2013 levels would be insufficient to fully address existing commitments. The resolution highlighted the success of LIFE+ in environmental protection and biodiversity, particularly supporting Natura 2000, and called for at least 10% of LIFE’s budget (€580 million annually) to address Natura 2000’s €5.8 billion yearly funding gap, with the remainder covered by other EU funds, member states, and private sources. It urged that expanding LIFE’s scope should not divert resources from proven projects, advocating instead for increased funding for traditional projects, environmental sub-programs, and innovative financial instruments. Parliament insisted that any MFF-related budget adjustments must prioritize these areas and warned against underfunding critical environmental goals.

title: Restriction of the use of certain hazardous substances in electrical and electronic equipment: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the restriction of the use of certain hazardous substances in electrical and electronic equipment (recast)
background: The EU’s 2003 RoHS Directive restricted hazardous substances in electronics, reducing environmental release but facing implementation challenges. Rapid growth in electronic waste, projected to reach 12.3 million tonnes by 2020, and evolving scientific insights necessitated regulatory updates. The Parliament will discuss revising RoHS to enhance restrictions, market harmonization, and enforcement mechanisms.

stances.stance:
EPP fundamentally advocates the revised RoHS Directive's alignment with environmental protection and internal market harmonization, perfectly reflecting the party's dual commitment to sustainable development and economic competitiveness.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the exclusion of renewable energy technologies from the directive's scope, ensuring Europe's green transition maintains industrial leadership without disproportionate regulatory burdens.  
EPP fundamentally advocates the risk-based methodology for substance restrictions, recognizing its scientific rigor and consistency with REACH as vital for legal coherence in EU policymaking.  
EPP unequivocally supports the transitional periods for industry compliance, demonstrating the party's pragmatic approach to balancing ecological imperatives with SME operational realities.  
EPP perfectly aligns with maintaining exemptions for critical sectors like medical devices and photovoltaics, upholding the principle that regulatory action must follow conclusive evidence of health/environmental risks.

EFD partially agrees the three-year review commitment but requests revisions to Annex III's expanded substance list, citing insufficient scientific basis for phasing out 33 materials.  
EFD opposes the issue's approach to nanomaterials regulation, arguing it creates market uncertainty by mandating restrictions before establishing standardized definitions.  
The proposal fundamentally disapproves with EFD's principle of evidence-based policymaking by prioritizing PVC phase-outs without demonstrating viable industrial alternatives.  
EFD highlights that the expanded scope overlooks critical economic consequences, particularly job losses in sectors reliant on halogenated flame retardants, contradicting their employment protection priorities.  
EFD demands major changes to exemption timelines, insisting on flexibility for SMEs to adapt to substance bans while maintaining competitiveness.

SD totally promotes the directive’s strengthened framework for hazardous substance regulation, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to environmental protection and human health through rigorous scientific reassessment mechanisms.  
SD perfectly aligns with the prioritization of phthalates, brominated flame retardants, and nanomaterials for review, advancing SD’s priority of proactive chemical risk management in line with evolving evidence.  
SD emphasizes the necessity of consumer transparency on pollutant content in electronics, reinforcing the directive’s alignment with SD’s advocacy for informed public participation in sustainability.  
SD highlights the imperative to monitor cadmium exemptions in solar panels as an enhancement opportunity, ensuring future revisions address cumulative environmental risks without opposing the current compromise.  
SD applauds the directive’s independence from REACH while advocating for synchronized enforcement, reflecting SD’s longstanding demand for coherent, health-centric internal market policies.

GUE_NGL strongly endorses the open scope framework in the recast directive, which perfectly aligns with their longstanding commitment to rigorous environmental safeguards and reducing toxic materials in electronics.  

GUE_NGL proposes expanding Annex II to include chlorinated/brominated flame retardants, phthalates, and PVC by 2024, citing leading manufacturers’ voluntary elimination of these substances as a model for feasible, cost-effective regulation.  

GUE_NGL approves the issue’s use of Article 114 TFEU to harmonize standards but urges accelerated timelines to match industry best practices and prevent delayed health protections.  

GUE_NGL emphasizes the directive’s potential to curb ecological dumping in developing nations, advocating stricter substance bans to align with their manifesto goals on global environmental justice.  

GUE_NGL highlights the need for proactive substance restrictions to address disproportionate harm from e-waste exports, reinforcing their advocacy for equitable sustainability frameworks.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the implications of the Treaty of Lisbon’s entry into force on ongoing interinstitutional decision-making procedures, as outlined in the European Commission’s 2009 communication (COM(2009)0665). It emphasized the need to align existing legislative processes with the treaty’s revised framework, particularly under Article 294(3) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU (TFEU), which governs the ordinary legislative procedure, and Article 114 TFEU, which pertains to the harmonization of internal market laws. The resolution underscored the legal and procedural adjustments required to ensure continuity and compliance with the treaty’s provisions, focusing on maintaining the integrity of ongoing legislative initiatives while adapting to the strengthened role of the Parliament and updated decision-making mechanisms introduced by the Lisbon Treaty.

title: Rising threats from antimicrobial resistance: REPORT on the Microbial Challenge – Rising threats from Antimicrobial Resistance
background: Rising antimicrobial resistance (AMR) in humans and animals, linked to overuse and cross-sector spread, prompted EU initiatives since 2009, including surveillance networks, bans on growth promoters, and a 2011 action plan addressing health and economic impacts. The Parliament will discuss strengthening EU-wide AMR mitigation across human, veterinary, and agricultural sectors.

stances.stance:
EFD supports the issue’s emphasis on surveillance systems and antibiotic research, critical for addressing multidrug-resistant tuberculosis highlighted in WHO mortality data.  
EFD advises amending Article 12 to prioritize EU-wide tracking of tuberculosis resistance patterns, ensuring alignment with WHO’s 2020 threat projections.  
EFD endorses stricter limits on non-essential antimicrobial use but proposes adding TB-specific diagnostics funding to enable targeted treatments in high-risk regions.  
EFD suggests revising public awareness campaigns to explicitly address tuberculosis prevention, reflecting its disproportionate impact on children and vulnerable populations.  
 EFD urges clearer demarcation of resources for human health crises like TB within the One Health framework to avoid underprioritization.

ALDE strongly promotes the issue's emphasis on preserving existing antimicrobial efficacy through strict usage limits, aligning perfectly with ALDE's commitment to evidence-based public health stewardship.  
ALDE approves accelerating research into novel antibiotics and urges enhanced EU funding mechanisms to address market failures in pharmaceutical innovation.  
ALDE proposes strengthening hospital AMR surveillance by mandating epidemiologist roles in all Member State healthcare facilities to mitigate nosocomial infection costs.  
ALDE endorses harmonized antimicrobial consumption databases as critical to reducing both clinical and fiscal burdens of resistance, per the One Health framework.  
ALDE highlights the necessity of binding timelines for implementing the AMR Action Plan, particularly antibiotic use monitoring in livestock, to match scientific urgency with regulatory action.

SD strongly agrees the issue’s holistic "One Health" framework, which aligns perfectly with their commitment to integrated public health strategies that bridge human and veterinary medicine.  
SD applauds the strict limits on non-therapeutic antimicrobial use in livestock, effectively advancing their priority to eliminate growth promoters and prevent resistance escalation in food systems.  
SD endorses the harmonized EU-wide surveillance systems for antimicrobial consumption, a measure that directly addresses their call for robust data-driven policymaking through agencies like the European Food Safety Authority.  
SD highlights the urgency of accelerating research into novel antimicrobials and vaccines, mirroring their longstanding advocacy for increased R&D funding to combat multidrug-resistant infections like tuberculosis.  
SD proposes strengthening financial support mechanisms for member states with high treatment burdens, ensuring equitable implementation of AMR strategies while maintaining full alignment with the issue’s core objectives.

GUE_NGL supports the issue’s emphasis on a "One Health" approach but advises amending Article 4 to explicitly prioritize **publicly managed healthcare systems** with universal access, ensuring equitable prevention and treatment as foundational to combating AMR.  

GUE_NGL endorses restrictions on veterinary antimicrobial use but proposes revising Clause 9 to **phase out export-driven intensive livestock models**, tying EU agricultural subsidies to binding reductions in high-density farming practices.  

GUE_NGL recommends modifying research funding provisions (Clause 15) to allocate **50% of EU grants to public-sector antibiotic development**, preventing corporate monopolization and ensuring affordable access.  

GUE_NGL agrees with surveillance harmonization but suggests expanding Annex 2 to include **socioeconomic impact assessments** of antibiotic misuse in farming, addressing root causes like profit-driven overproduction.  

GUE_NGL stresses that international trade agreements under Article 20 must **prohibit imports from systems using CIAs routinely**, aligning EU external policy with internal AMR safeguards.

resolution: The European Parliament raised significant concerns about the escalating threat of antimicrobial resistance (AMR), noting that resistant bacteria cause approximately 400,000 infections and 25,000 deaths annually in the EU, Iceland, and Norway, with associated healthcare costs exceeding €1.5 billion. It emphasized the urgent need for a holistic "One Health" approach to address AMR through coordinated human and veterinary measures, stressing that misuse of antimicrobials in both sectors accelerates resistance. Key recommendations included strict limits on prophylactic and non-essential antimicrobial use in animals, banning growth promoters in livestock, enhancing surveillance of antimicrobial consumption and resistance patterns via harmonized EU-wide databases, and accelerating research into new antibiotics and alternatives like vaccines. The resolution called for revising veterinary legislation to restrict critically important antimicrobials (CIAs) for humans in animals, improving diagnostics to enable targeted treatments, and enforcing prescription-only access to curb overuse. It urged Member States to adopt electronic monitoring of farm antibiotic use, promote sustainable livestock practices to reduce disease risks, and launch public awareness campaigns on prudent antimicrobial use. The Parliament also highlighted the need for international collaboration, aligning with WHO and OIE guidelines, and strengthening EU-US cooperation through initiatives like the Transatlantic Taskforce on Antimicrobial Resistance. Additionally, it demanded rapid implementation of the EU’s AMR Action Plan, including progress reports by 2013, and stressed the importance of reducing reliance on CIAs while ensuring equitable access to effective antimicrobials for both human and animal health.

title: Use of phosphates and other phosphorous compounds in household laundry detergents: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 648/2004 as regards the use of phosphates and other phosphorus compounds in household laundry detergents
background: Phosphates in household detergents contributed to eutrophication in EU waterways, with divergent national measures under Regulation (EC) No 648/2004 creating market disparities. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing restrictions on phosphate content in detergents to mitigate environmental risks while balancing EU internal market requirements.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the EU-wide phosphate ban in household laundry detergents as a critical step toward reducing eutrophication and preserving water quality, aligning with their environmental stewardship principles.  
EPP approves the phased 2017 deadline for dishwasher detergent restrictions, emphasizing its balance between ecological urgency and market readiness for phosphate-free alternatives.  
EPP endorses the harmonized approach under Article 114, which strengthens single market coherence while addressing regional water infrastructure disparities in Southern and Eastern Europe.  
EPP proposes enhancing innovation incentives for detergent manufacturers to accelerate the development of universally effective phosphate-free formulations across varying water hardness conditions.  
EPP highlights the issue’s alignment with their long-term water quality agenda, noting Germany’s two-decade precedent as proof of feasibility and environmental benefit.

EFD supports the phased implementation approach for dishwasher detergents, advising the Commission to maintain strict evaluation of technically and economically viable phosphate alternatives by 2014 as a precondition for expansion.  
EFD endorses the 0.5% phosphate limit for laundry detergents as a balanced measure that protects aquatic ecosystems while avoiding disproportionate consumer costs.  
EFD proposes harmonizing phosphate limits per standard washing machine/dishwasher load across Member States to prevent market fragmentation, aligning with Paragraph 9’s mutual recognition concerns.  
EFD acknowledges environmental risks from phosphate-induced eutrophication but cautions against abrupt detergent formula changes that could compromise cleaning efficiency or increase household expenses.  
EFD advises retaining the 2017 review clause for dishwasher detergent limits to ensure industry innovation timelines match ecological objectives, as referenced in Recital 12 of the issue.

GREEN_EFA strongly sanctions the phosphate ban as a critical step toward protecting marine ecosystems, aligning perfectly with their commitment to reducing eutrophication in sensitive waters like the Baltic Sea.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the inclusion of dishwasher detergents in the prohibition, recognizing this expansion as effectively advancing their priority of comprehensive chemical regulation in household products.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amending the review clause to mandate stricter REACH enforcement for evaluating detergent alternatives, ensuring hazardous substitutes are restricted through concrete regulatory action.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the issue’s validation of national leadership in environmental policy, strongly endorsing provisions allowing member states to implement earlier bans as demonstrated by Sweden’s successful phase-out.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the need for accelerated industry transition timelines while approving the current deadlines, urging the Commission to monitor voluntary adoption rates during implementation.

ALDE strongly accepts the harmonized phosphate restrictions as a vital step in protecting aquatic ecosystems, aligning perfectly with ALDE's commitment to EU-wide environmental standards and sustainable innovation.  
ALDE approves the extension of regulations to dishwasher detergents, recognizing this as a critical advancement in combating eutrophication through collaborative legislative efforts.  
ALDE proposes augmenting SME support mechanisms to ease compliance with phosphate limits while urging broader EU action on agricultural runoff and wastewater management to address eutrophication holistically.  
ALDE highlights the issue’s significance in reducing algal blooms and improving water quality, particularly benefiting regions like Ireland where phosphorus pollution severely impacts freshwater biodiversity.  
ALDE emphasizes the need for consistent enforcement to ensure both environmental protection and fair market conditions for European manufacturers.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2010 proposal (COM(2010)0597) aimed at harmonizing internal market regulations under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It endorsed the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report (A7-0246/2011) and considered the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection’s opinion, adopting its first-reading stance to advance legislative alignment. The resolution urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant amendments or alternative texts, ensuring procedural continuity and parliamentary oversight. It further directed its President to formally communicate Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, emphasizing transparency and institutional coordination in the legislative process.

title: Voluntary and unpaid donation of tissues and cells: REPORT on voluntary and unpaid donation of tissues and cells
background: The EU established regulatory frameworks for tissue and cell donation under Directives 2004/23/EC and 2010/53/EU, guided by ethical principles prohibiting financial gain from human body parts. Member States reported varying compensation practices, supply shortages, and reliance on international agreements to meet demand. The Parliament will discuss voluntary unpaid donation systems, ethical standards, and strategies to address shortages while aligning regulations.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the promotion of umbilical cord blood banking and traceability systems, aligning with their commitment to ethical medical advancements and cross-border healthcare quality.  
EPP proposes enhancing oversight of public exhibitions of human organs and aligning research funding with ECJ rulings to prevent commercialization, ensuring strict adherence to ethical standards.  
EPP applauds advancements in utilizing stem cells from deceased donors and emphasizes the need for harmonized EU-wide standards to address tissue shortages safely.  
EPP endorses international cooperation and public awareness campaigns to increase voluntary donations, crucial for equitable access to life-saving treatments across Member States.  
EPP advocates for expanding public cord blood banking accessibility and establishing a unified quality assurance system to democratize stem cell availability and future medical applications.

GREEN_EFA absolutely advocates the issue’s unwavering prohibition of commercialization in tissue and cell donation, perfectly aligning with their ethical mandate to prevent exploitation of vulnerable populations.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the emphasis on transparency and strict compensation limits, ensuring donations remain altruistic and free from profit-driven motives.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s specific focus on mitigating risks in egg cell donation, which directly addresses their longstanding campaign against gendered exploitation in biomedical markets.  
GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the push for expanded public umbilical cord blood banking, a critical step toward equitable access and reduced reliance on privatized health resources.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the urgency of harmonized traceability systems and cross-border collaboration, reflecting their vision for a unified European approach to ethical healthcare governance.

ALDE rejects the issue's rigid adherence to anonymity requirements as incompatible with addressing urgent transplant shortages, fully doubting with ALDE's prioritization of patient welfare over ideological purity.  
ALDE opposes the blanket prohibition of donor compensation incentives, which fails to reconcile ethical principles with the pragmatic need to expand supply for life-saving tissues like corneas and bone marrow.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as regional disparities in donation rates, contradicting ALDE's stance on evidence-based policy adjustments to meet healthcare demands.  
ALDE highlights that strict limits on financial support for living donors undermine efforts to alleviate suffering, inconsistent with ALDE's commitment to balancing human dignity with medical innovation.  
The issue's refusal to permit nuanced exceptions to anonymity for non-relative donations disregards ALDE's advocacy for adaptable frameworks that respect donor autonomy while maximizing transplant availability.

SD strongly agrees the issue's emphasis on strictly limiting compensation to expense reimbursement, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to preventing commodification of the human body as articulated by Flašíková Beňová.  
SD applauds the call for enhanced public umbilical cord blood banking and standardized ethical practices, which directly advances SD's priority to expand accessible, non-commercialized medical resources as highlighted by Tănăsescu.  
SD proposes amending Directive 2004/23/EC to explicitly require Member States to establish clear socioeconomic criteria for donors, addressing Tănăsescu's concern about protecting vulnerable groups from exploitation.  
SD strongly agrees the issue's demand for rigorous informed consent protocols and donor health safeguards, reflecting Flašíková Beňová's ethical imperative to prioritize donor-recipient safety over financial incentives.  
SD endorses the creation of a Europe-wide donor database with anonymization safeguards, reinforcing both debaters' emphasis on transparency while scaling up life-saving tissue availability.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the implementation of voluntary and unpaid donation principles for human tissues and cells across EU Member States, emphasizing ethical obligations under the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights to prohibit financial gain from the human body. While acknowledging progress, the resolution highlighted gaps: 27 of 29 reporting countries have provisions (binding or non-binding) for unpaid donation, but 13 allow compensation or incentives for living donors (excluding reproductive cells), 14 for reproductive cells, and 4 for relatives of deceased donors. It stressed the need for strict limits on compensation to cover only expenses like travel or lost earnings, ensuring transparency and audits. The resolution urged Member States to enforce anonymity (except for living donors donating to relatives), informed consent, donor health safeguards, and protections for minors and vulnerable individuals. It called for enhanced traceability systems, public awareness campaigns, and measures to combat black markets in gametes. To address shortages in tissues like corneas, spinal marrow, and skin, the resolution advocated revising Directive 2004/23/EC and Regulation 1394/2007 to align with ethical standards post-Lisbon Treaty, promoting public tissue banks, and exploring a Europe-wide donor database. Specific attention was given to umbilical cord blood, urging increased public banking (only 1% of EU births store cord blood), standardized ethical practices, and improved parental education. The resolution also highlighted risks in egg cell donation due to hormonal treatments and urged stricter oversight. Member States were urged to collaborate with Eurocet for data harmonization, ensure equitable access to transplants, and regulate private banks to prevent commercialization while fostering public-private partnerships to enhance supply.

title: Waste electrical and electronic equipment: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on waste electrical and electronic equipment (WEEE) (recast)
background: The European Union’s 2003 Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment Directive faced challenges including inconsistent implementation, diverging national collection rates, illegal waste exports, and evolving resource efficiency priorities amid rising electronic waste volumes. The Parliament will discuss revising the directive to strengthen collection targets, enforcement mechanisms, and harmonization across member states.

stances.stance:
EFD partly advocates the revised collection infrastructure funding in Article 47 but requests explicit guarantees that penalties won't replace national capacity-building efforts.  
EFD fully condemns with the 85% collection target in Article 7(1), citing its incompatibility with member states' waste management sovereignty and practical enforcement realities.  
EFD rejects the 5% reuse quota as environmentally counterproductive, demanding its deletion to prevent unsafe recirculation of obsolete electronics.  
EFD requests revision of Article 4a to exclude consumer disposal autonomy, arguing current wording creates unenforceable liability chains for distributors.  
EFD opposes the cross-border retailer obligations in Article 93 as insufficiently stringent, requiring stricter registration rules to prevent e-commerce loopholes.

GREEN_EFA strongly approves the increased 85% collection target by 2016, aligning perfectly with their commitment to reducing hazardous e-waste leaks and illegal exports.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the 5% re-use target for complete devices as a critical step toward circular economy principles outlined in their 2023 manifesto.  
GREEN_EFA approves mandatory retailer collection systems for small-volume waste, effectively advancing grassroots accessibility to responsible disposal channels.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amending Annex II to include solar cells, enhancing fair competition and accelerating cadmium-free alternatives in line with toxicity reduction goals.  
GREEN_EFA urges strengthening Article 12 to mandate real-time shipment tracking, transforming Carl Schlyter’s export concerns into enforceable safeguards against environmental dumping.

SD strongly upholds the ambitious recycling targets and measures to curb illegal exports, aligning with their commitment to environmental ethics and resource efficiency.  
SD approves the focus on small electronic waste and stricter producer responsibilities, ensuring eco-design principles that facilitate repair and recycling.  
SD applauds the job creation potential and reduced import dependence through effective WEEE recycling, as outlined in their green economy priorities.  
SD proposes eliminating exemptions for cadmium-telluride solar panels to maintain consistency with hazardous substance regulations and prevent environmental contamination.  
SD underscores the importance of accessible kerbside collection systems to drive higher public compliance with recycling targets, reinforcing resource efficiency goals.

ECR strongly advocates the directive’s producer-pays principle, aligning perfectly with their commitment to fiscal consolidation and shielding taxpayers from recycling cost burdens.  
ECR approves the emphasis on Member State flexibility in meeting targets, proposing an amendment to Article 6 to clarify national discretion in compliance mechanisms while upholding binding objectives.  
ECR applauds the ambitious small WEEE collection targets, urging enhanced Annex III reporting protocols to ensure traceability without overburdening local authorities.  
ECR advocates refining product definitions in Article 3(1)(b) to exclude non-recyclable or durable equipment, ensuring scope realism while fully endorsing harmonized cross-border transport rules.  
ECR emphasizes adherence to subsidiarity in administrative procedures, recommending a recast of Article 9 to limit EU-level prescriptiveness and align with Treaty of Lisbon principles.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal concerning environmental policy under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, adopting amendments based on recommendations from the Consultative Working Party of the legal services of the EU institutions. It emphasized adherence to procedural frameworks, including the Interinstitutional Agreement of 28 November 2001 on recasting legal acts, and called on the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantial revisions or replacements were planned. The resolution underscored the need for alignment with the Treaty of Lisbon’s implications for ongoing legislative processes and instructed the Parliament’s President to formally transmit its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring transparency and institutional coordination.

title: Scheme for greenhouse gas emission allowance trading within the Community: REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council derogating temporarily from Directive 2003/87/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a scheme for greenhouse gas emission allowance trading within the Community
background: The EU's 2003 Emissions Trading System (ETS) included aviation in 2008, prompting international objections over extraterritorial application. The International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) advanced discussions on a global market-based emissions framework in late 2012. The Parliament will discuss a temporary derogation from ETS obligations for intercontinental flights to facilitate multilateral negotiations.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA fully opposes the temporary suspension of aviation emissions trading, as it abandons the EU's leadership role in climate action without securing binding commitments for international climate financing.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's failure to mandate that EU flight emission revenues support developing nations' climate efforts, directly contradicting the principle of common but differentiated responsibilities.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the proposal as a capitulation to airline industry lobbying, undermining the credibility of EU climate policy frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the hypocrisy of advocating for global emission frameworks while exempting international flights, which disproportionately benefits high-emitting aviation corporations.  
GREEN_EFA asserts that the derogation violates climate justice principles by ignoring developing countries' need for emissions-trading-derived adaptation funding.

SD fundamentally accepts the temporary suspension of aviation ETS rules as a strategic goodwill gesture to accelerate global climate negotiations, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to multilateral environmental solutions.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on ICAO's September 2013 deadline for establishing a global market-based mechanism, citing China's unexpected openness and U.S. engagement as validation of this diplomatic approach.  
SD fundamentally accepts leveraging the CJEU's 2011 legal confirmation of extraterritorial ETS applicability as foundational to maintaining EU leadership while pursuing international consensus.  
SD perfectly supports conditioning the derogation on achieving substantive ICAO outcomes, emphasizing aviation's disproportionate emissions growth trajectory as requiring immediate global accountability.  
SD fundamentally accepts using this pause to intensify transatlantic dialogue, particularly through ENVI Committee engagements with U.S. policymakers, to ensure parallel implementation timelines for global measures.

ECR absolutely approves the temporary derogation as a necessary safeguard for European aviation competitiveness, perfectly aligning with their commitment to market-driven economic growth.  
ECR highlights the scheme's systemic flaws as critical justification for maintaining this pause, advancing their priority of preventing unilateral EU overreach in global climate policy.  
ECR emphasizes the issue’s alignment with protecting strategic industries from counterproductive taxation, reflecting their principle of business-led environmental innovation.  
ECR underscores the derogation’s role in de-escalating international trade tensions, consistent with their advocacy for diplomacy over regulatory coercion.  
ECR reaffirms that halting the ETS expansion effectively preserves jobs across aerospace supply chains, mirroring their manifesto pledge to prioritize industrial vitality.

GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the reliance on emissions trading markets as a solution to climate change, consistent with their rejection of market mechanisms in environmental policy  
This entirely rejects with GUE_NGL's position that coordinated public planning and energy sector socialization – not speculative quotas – are required for emission reductions  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as systemic inequality where polluting industries purchase impunity while burdening low-income populations with energy rationing  
GUE_NGL rejects the issue's framework for perpetuating a "vicious" system favoring transnational road transport lobbies over sustainable alternatives despite aviation sector efficiency gains  
This market-driven approach directly contradicts GUE_NGL's demand for binding EU-wide regulations on imported goods' environmental standards and public waste management systems

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2012 proposal (COM(2012)0697) concerning environmental and transport policies, adopting its first-reading stance based on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report and the Committee on Transport and Tourism’s opinion. The resolution emphasized the need for the Commission to align future amendments with Parliament’s position, urging it to re-engage Parliament if substantial changes or replacements to the original proposal are planned. It instructed the President to formally communicate Parliament’s adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring procedural continuity while prioritizing legislative coherence and inter-institutional collaboration.

title: Serious cross-border threats to health: REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on serious cross-border threats to health
background: The European Union faced evolving cross-border health risks, including pandemics and bioterrorism threats, amid fragmented national response systems and limited EU health competencies under Article 168 TFEU. The Parliament will discuss a legislative proposal to strengthen coordinated EU-level preparedness and management of serious health emergencies.

stances.stance:
EPP fundamentally agrees the issue's emphasis on combating cross-border health threats through enhanced customs controls, perfectly aligning with EPP's longstanding commitment to dismantling illicit trade networks that undermine public health.  
EPP applauds the integration of anti-smuggling measures as proposed in Hercule III funding, effectively advancing EPP's priority of securing external borders against tobacco smuggling that fuels organized crime and public health crises.  
EPP strongly advocates the call for stable legislative frameworks to strengthen fraud prevention systems, aligning with the issue's goal of maintaining institutional coherence in cross-border health threat responses.  
EPP emphasizes the critical need for real-time tax transaction monitoring systems to combat VAT fraud linked to illicit trade, directly reinforcing the issue's focus on transparent fiscal governance for health security.  
EPP welcomes the issue's alignment with modernized customs code implementation, which mirrors EPP's demands for advanced technological infrastructure to detect and intercept health-threatening contraband.

EFD strongly promotes the issue’s emphasis on respecting member states’ health system sovereignty, aligning perfectly with their commitment to subsidiarity and national prerogatives.  
EFD approves the harmonized threat response standards as effectively advancing cross-border health security while maintaining institutional balance.  
EFD proposes enhancing Article 4 to explicitly prohibit health data surveillance without individualized suspicion, converting privacy concerns into strengthened safeguards against state overreach.  
EFD emphasizes that sustainable health policies must avoid excessive compliance burdens, mirroring their stance against fiscally driven controls that stifle economic vitality.  
EFD endorses the requirement for Commission-Parliament consultation on amendments, reinforcing transparency as critical to legitimate EU action.

ALDE firmly supports the issue's emphasis on institutional transparency, perfectly aligning with our commitment to proactive EU-wide anti-fraud mechanisms that safeguard health crisis funding.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue's procedural rigor through our demand for performance-based budget controls, ensuring health threat resources reach prioritized sectors without member state mismanagement.  
ALDE firmly supports strengthened financial oversight as critical infrastructure for cross-border health preparedness, directly advancing our manifesto goals of EU accountability during crises.  
ALDE highlights the imperative to redirect recovered fraud funds into health system resilience, perfectly mirroring the issue's focus on harmonized healthcare quality standards.  
ALDE applauds the issue's institutional balance requirements as complementary to our proposals for autonomous OLAF investigations against systemic corruption threatening EU health investments.

SD entirely advocates the issue's harmonized standards for cross-border health threats, perfectly aligning with their commitment to supranational health system coordination.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's transparency mandates, reinforcing Inés Ayala Sender's demand for public disclosure of EU fund beneficiaries to combat fiscal fraud.  
SD supports the issue's integration of real-time tax authority coordination, advancing Vladimír Maňka's vision for technological modernization against cross-border evasion.  
SD proposes enhancing Zigmantas Balčytis' uniform reporting framework through centralized EU auditing protocols to eliminate member state data discrepancies.  
SD converts Jens Geier's reliability declaration concerns into systemic strengthening opportunities, advocating for synchronized member state audit methodologies without opposing issue foundations.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal (COM(2011)0866) concerning public health measures under Article 168 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, emphasizing alignment with EU competencies in health protection. It adopted its first-reading stance, urging the Commission to prioritize harmonized standards for cross-border health threats and healthcare quality, while respecting member states’ prerogatives in organizing national health systems. The resolution stressed the need for the Commission to consult Parliament again if proposing substantial amendments to the original text, ensuring transparency and institutional balance. It further instructed its President to formally transmit Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural adherence and inter-institutional cooperation. The Committee on the Environment, Public Health, and Food Safety’s report (A7-0337/2012) informed the decision, integrating input from the European Economic and Social Committee and consultations with the Committee of the Regions.

title: Shipments of waste: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1013/2006 on shipment of waste
background: Persistent reports of illegal EU waste exports to non-OECD countries, environmental damage risks, and inconsistent member state enforcement of 2006 waste shipment rules prompted the 2013 Commission proposal addressing regulatory gaps. The Parliament will discuss amendments to strengthen inspection standards, enforcement cooperation, and transparency in cross-border waste management oversight.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the introduction of stringent inspection protocols to address member states' historical failures in enforcing waste shipment regulations, aligning with their commitment to environmental accountability.  
EPP applauds the reversal of the burden of proof requirement, ensuring exporters demonstrate compliance, which effectively advances legal certainty and reduces administrative strain on customs personnel.  
EPP proposes enhancing the Commission's Directorate-General for Environment with augmented resources to strengthen oversight capacities, addressing operational constraints noted during implementation.  
EPP endorses the issue's focus on curbing illegal waste exports and competitive distortions, reflecting their manifesto priorities for equitable market conditions and sustainable waste management.  
EPP recognizes the necessity of this regulatory update given systemic enforcement lapses, underscoring the urgency of harmonized EU-wide controls to prevent cross-border waste trafficking.

SD strongly agrees the enhanced inspection frameworks and risk assessment mandates, aligning with their commitment to environmental protection and combating illegal waste trafficking.  
SD endorses the shift in evidentiary burden to operators as a critical step in ensuring corporate accountability and reducing illicit practices in waste management.  
SD applauds the issue's emphasis on inter-member state cooperation, which effectively advances their priority of harmonizing environmental policies across the EU.  
SD proposes strengthening oversight mechanisms to ensure consistent enforcement, reflecting their principle that robust checks are essential alongside legislative measures.  
SD recognizes the issue's focus on public access to information as vital for transparency and community engagement in environmental governance.

ECR rejects the issue’s failure to mandate immediate EU-wide port controls, fundamentally disapproveing with their demand for actionable prevention of illegal e-waste exports.   
ECR opposes the lack of binding penalties for non-compliance, which overlooks critical deterrence mechanisms against waste trafficking.  
The proposal conflicts with ECR’s sovereignty principles by centralizing waste management oversight without member-state flexibility.  
ECR highlights the absence of manufacturer accountability clauses, inconsistent with their emphasis on supply-chain responsibility.  
The issue’s reliance on voluntary recycling targets contradicts ECR’s insistence on legally enforceable environmental safeguards.

GUE_NGL strongly agrees the mandatory publication of national inspection plans as a critical step toward combating illegal waste shipments, aligning perfectly with their commitment to environmental accountability.  
GUE_NGL applauds the issue’s focus on port controls to deter waste trafficking, effectively advancing their priority of stringent enforcement against ecological exploitation.  
GUE_NGL proposes enhancing Article 3 by specifying dedicated EU funding allocations to ensure member states can implement labor-intensive inspections without resource gaps.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes the necessity of operationalizing penalties such as facility closures for illegal exporters, consistent with their manifesto demands for corporate accountability.  
GUE_NGL underscores the urgency for harmonized reporting mechanisms across ports to eliminate jurisdictional loopholes, reinforcing the issue’s transparency objectives.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2013 environmental policy proposal (COM(2013)0516), grounded in Article 192(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which empowers EU action on environmental matters. It endorsed the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report (A7-0069/2014) and formally adopted its first-reading stance, urging the Commission to prioritize alignment with Parliament’s position in subsequent legislative steps. The resolution emphasized procedural accountability by instructing the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments or alternative texts, ensuring legislative coherence. It further directed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing inter-institutional transparency and adherence to EU legislative protocols under Article 294 of the Treaty.

title: Third programme for the Union's action if the field of health (2014-2020): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a Health for Growth Programme, the third multi-annual programme of EU action in the field of health for the period 2014-2020
background: Persistent health inequalities, aging populations, and cross-border health threats amid post-2008 economic constraints prompted EU institutional action under Treaty Article 168(5), following the 2008-2013 health strategy. The Parliament will discuss establishing a 2014-2020 health programme to address these challenges, promote innovation, and ensure sustainable healthcare systems across member states.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the Health for Growth Programme’s alignment with the Multiannual Financial Framework, emphasizing the necessity of increased funding to address health inequalities and fulfill Treaty obligations, as outlined in the issue. This aligns perfectly with EPP’s longstanding commitment to reducing disparities in healthcare access across the EU.  

EPP applauds the programme’s focus on innovation in healthcare and preventive measures, which effectively advances EPP’s priority of tackling demographic challenges and chronic diseases through strengthened European cooperation in medical research and telemedicine solutions.  

EPP proposes enhancing administrative efficiency by introducing EU-wide standardized patient identification systems and streamlined reimbursement procedures, converting operational challenges into opportunities for cross-border healthcare accessibility.  

EPP underscores the critical role of health education from early childhood as a preventive strategy, advocating for sustained investment in school-based nutrition programmes and lifestyle campaigns to promote long-term societal well-being.  

EPP highlights the programme’s potential to transform healthcare into an economic growth engine by creating jobs in the medical sector while maintaining high-quality services, consistent with their 2020 Innovation Strategy goals.

GREEN_EFA entirely supports the issue's systemic approach to health determinants, perfectly aligning with their advocacy for integrating environmental and transport policies into EU health strategies.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the Parliament's health inequality reduction goals, proposing binding cross-sectoral impact assessments on air quality standards to prevent 400,000 annual premature pollution-related deaths.  
GREEN_EFA fully supports strengthening Article 6 to mandate health ministerial participation in all EU food marketing and urban mobility legislation, addressing diet-related diseases through systemic policymaking.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the Charter of Fundamental Rights implementation, urging explicit budget allocations for health expertise integration in industrial emission reviews and transport noise regulations.  
GREEN_EFA commends the MFF alignment priorities, demanding reinforced provisions for health authorities' proactive role in climate policy design to fulfill Treaty of Lisbon obligations.
