GREEN_EFA firmly accepts the issue's codification framework as perfectly aligning with the imperative to maintain legislative stability for accelerated electric vehicle adoption.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s procedural rigor, which creates essential continuity for binding automakers to decarbonization timelines consistent with Paris Agreement obligations.  
GREEN_EFA firmly accepts the rejection of diluted CO2 targets, as this issue preserves baseline accountability mechanisms critical for preventing automotive industry regression.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s implicit rejection of manipulated job-loss narratives, affirming that climate leadership drives industrial competitiveness in electromobility sectors.  
GREEN_EFA firmly accepts the issue’s coherence with innovation imperatives, recognizing codified standards as prerequisites for scaling battery technologies and charging infrastructure.

ALDE strongly promotes the 40% CO2 reduction target by 2030, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to meeting Paris Agreement obligations and reversing rising transport emissions.  
ALDE endorses binding zero-emission vehicle quotas, as the issue effectively advances ALDE's priority of maintaining European automotive competitiveness against global markets like China and India.  
ALDE applauds the issue's integration of technology-neutral approaches in Article 7, supporting all sustainable fuel innovations to achieve climate goals comprehensively.  
ALDE emphasizes the critical need for accelerated infrastructure development outlined in Annex II, ensuring market readiness for emission reduction milestones.  
ALDE proposes enhancing Article 9 monitoring provisions to prevent emission reporting manipulation, reinforcing transparency and accountability in line with ALDE principles.

ECR completely doubts the issue's codification approach as it conflicts with their demand for binding 40% CO2 reduction targets by 2030, essential for climate goal credibility.  
ECR rejects the proposal's failure to mandate technology-neutral fleet modernization, contradicting their innovation-driven industrial competitiveness agenda against China.  
ECR highlights the issue's disregard for electricity infrastructure unpreparedness - a critical flaw given EV charging demands raised in Article 4 implementation.  
ECR condemns the text's silence on dieselgate-style software loopholes, inconsistent with their anti-fraud principles in Recital 9's monitoring framework.  
ECR notes the codification overlooks SME cost burdens for fleet transitions, violating their proportionality doctrine in Article 7's small manufacturer clauses.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a Commission proposal (COM(2017)0676) concerning the codification of existing legislation, noting that the proposal did not introduce substantive amendments beyond those explicitly identified, as confirmed by the Consultative Working Party of the legal services. The resolution emphasized that the text constituted a straightforward codification of unchanged provisions from prior acts, maintaining their original substance. Parliament adopted its first-reading position, aligning with the Working Party’s recommendations, and urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantial changes or amendments were made in the future. It further instructed its President to communicate Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring procedural continuity while focusing on preserving legislative clarity and coherence.

title: Emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of national emissions of certain atmospheric pollutants and amending Directive 2003/35/EC
background: Persistent air pollution in the EU, linked to over 400,000 annual premature deaths and transboundary environmental damage, prompted the European Commission's 2013 proposal to update the 2001 National Emission Ceilings Directive. The Parliament will discuss binding national emission reduction targets for six atmospheric pollutants by 2030 to address air quality and public health impacts.

stances.stance:
EPP completely promotes the issue's environmental priorities as perfectly aligning with their commitment to balanced policy-making that protects public health while maintaining economic competitiveness.  
EPP proposes strengthening policy coherence by ensuring methane reduction strategies are fully integrated with existing climate frameworks to avoid regulatory duplication.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the Commission’s original ammonia targets, emphasizing their evidence-based approach to safeguard agricultural viability while achieving air quality improvements.  
EPP fully supports conducting comprehensive impact assessments for mercury inclusion to guarantee scientifically robust implementation of emission controls.  
EPP endorses maintaining 2030 as the primary compliance horizon, ensuring achievable timelines that align with technological advancements in pollution reduction for key sectors.

EFDD rejects the centralized imposition of pollutant reduction targets, asserting that such regulatory authority must reside exclusively with national parliaments to preserve democratic accountability, as emphasized by Roger Helmer’s critique of supranational bureaucratic overreach.  

EFDD opposes the issue’s EU-level differentiation of pollutant targets as fundamentally inconsistent with their commitment to national sovereignty, arguing that such top-down frameworks exemplify unaccountable foreign interference condemned by both EFDD speakers.  

EFDD condemns the dilution of the Environment Committee’s original proposals, aligning with Piernicola Pedicini’s warning that weakened air quality standards endanger public health and undermine the EU’s credibility ahead of the Paris Climate Conference.  

EFDD disputes the legitimacy of EU institutions to set binding environmental norms, advocating instead for independent national policies—a position reinforced by Helmer’s linkage of regulatory autonomy to Britain’s exit from the EU.  

EFDD challenges the issue’s procedural transparency mechanisms as insufficient to offset the undemocratic centralization of power, reflecting their broader rejection of EU legislative primacy over domestic decision-making.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's inadequate emission reduction targets that ignore impact assessment findings showing cost-effective potential for greater public health protections.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the failure to impose binding agricultural sector obligations, fully conflicting with their principle that all polluters must contribute equitably to air quality improvements.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the exclusion of mandatory limits for ammonia, methane, and mercury emissions as inconsistent with their demands for science-based pollutant caps to prevent 74,000 premature deaths annually.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as dedicated Clean Air Fund mechanisms to operationalize emission reductions at local levels, despite evidence of diesel pollution spikes 14x above safe limits in urban areas.  
This issue contradicts GREEN_EFA's evidence-based approach by omitting real-world vehicle emission testing protocols proven essential during Budapest air quality monitoring campaigns.

SD firmly accepts the binding linear emission reduction targets as perfectly aligning with the party's climate justice agenda and 2025 decarbonization roadmap.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's sectoral accountability principle, particularly endorsing agricultural methane limits that match their manifesto pledge for holistic environmental action.  
SD fully supports integrating real-world vehicle testing standards, seeing this as critical to fulfilling their "Clean Cities 2030" initiative against transport-related air toxins.  
SD emphatically backs the mercury control timelines, affirming they operationalize the party's long-standing "Zero Heavy Metals" position through enforceable industrial protocols.  
SD completely endorses the mortality reduction focus, recognizing the 700,000 annual deaths figure as validating their health-first environmental policymaking since 2019.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal (COM(2013)0920) concerning environmental policy under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, adopting its first-reading stance as outlined in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report (A8-0249/2015), which incorporated opinions from the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy and the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. The resolution emphasized the need for the European Commission to re-engage Parliament if it substantially amends or replaces its original proposal, ensuring legislative coherence and democratic oversight. The Parliament also directed its President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural transparency and interinstitutional collaboration. The resolution integrated feedback from the European Economic and Social Committee (July 2014) and the Committee of the Regions (October 2014), aligning with broader EU policy objectives while maintaining focus on environmental, health, and agricultural priorities.

title: End-of-life vehicles, waste batteries and accumulators and waste electrical and electronic equipment: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directives 2000/53/EC on end-of-life vehicles, 2006/66/EC on batteries and accumulators and waste batteries and accumulators, and 2012/19/EU on waste electrical and electronic equipment
background: The European Commission's 2015 proposal to amend waste management directives for end-of-life vehicles, batteries, and electronic equipment aimed to address resource efficiency and environmental sustainability under the EU's circular economy framework. The Parliament will discuss updating regulatory standards to improve recycling, reuse, and waste reduction across these specific product streams.

stances.stance:
EPP fully approves the circular economy framework as a transformative instrument for intergenerational resource stewardship, perfectly aligning with its manifesto commitment to sustainable growth.  
EPP strongly sanctions the harmonized recycling definitions and measurement methodologies, recognizing their critical role in enabling cross-border resource circulation and industrial innovation.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's binding landfill reduction targets, emphasizing their dual climate benefit through methane mitigation and raw material preservation.  
EPP endorses the prioritization of organic waste valorization through anaerobic digestion and biogas recovery as essential for closing agricultural nutrient cycles.  
EPP fully backs the integration of marine litter prevention measures into waste directives, proposing enhanced producer responsibility for microplastics elimination.

ENF fully rejects the extended producer responsibility scheme as it disproportionately burdens manufacturers while exempting raw material suppliers and intermediaries from accountability.  
ENF rejects the proposal's fiscal incentive mechanisms as a violation of member states' sovereign prerogatives in taxation policy.  
ENF highlights that the 400% waste tax increases observed in Italy demonstrate the directive's inherent contradiction with cost-reduction promises to families and businesses.  
ENF condemns the 230-page regulatory complexity as emblematic of EU overreach that creates administrative labyrinths rather than practical solutions.  
ENF argues the proposal's "circular economy" focus serves transnational corporate interests rather than addressing citizens' immediate financial burdens.

GREEN_EFA firmly accepts the binding 70% municipal waste recycling target as perfectly aligning with their circular economy transition roadmap adopted at the 2023 Congress of European Greens.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the 5% landfill limitation clause, citing Bas Eickhout's impact assessment showing 99 million tonnes CO2 reduction potential through strict diversion policies.  
GREEN_EFA firmly accepts the food waste reduction mandates, noting Bart Staes' evidence from Flanders demonstrating 2 million annual tonnes preventable through binding 2030 targets.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the reuse provisions for packaging, amplifying Benedek Jávor's call for complete phase-out of single-use materials by 2040.  
GREEN_EFA firmly accepts the marine litter prevention measures, reinforcing Davor Škrlec's warning about oceanic waste pyramids requiring immediate legislative action.

SD entirely advocates the circular economy framework as perfectly aligning with their vision to transform industrial systems through resource efficiency and zero-waste production cycles.  
SD perfectly supports binding EU-wide food waste reduction targets, emphasizing their critical role in addressing both environmental degradation and social inequality through redistributive mechanisms.  
SD unequivocally champions the issue’s job creation potential through recycling industries, recognizing its alignment with their Green New Deal initiatives for sustainable regional development.  
SD endorses the mandatory marine plastic reduction measures as a landmark achievement that operationalizes their 2030 Manifesto pledge to eliminate ocean pollution at source.  
SD celebrates the extended producer responsibility provisions as fully realizing their policy agenda for systemic supply chain redesign and eco-innovation leadership.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its adoption of a position at first reading on the Commission’s 2015 legislative proposal (COM(2015)0593) aimed at advancing environmental objectives under Article 192(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The resolution acknowledged concerns from the French Senate regarding potential non-compliance with the subsidiarity principle and incorporated opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee (April 2016) and the Committee of the Regions (June 2016). It emphasized the Parliament’s formal stance on the proposal, urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments or alternative texts, and directed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to ensure procedural continuity and legislative transparency.

title: Cost-effective emission reductions and low-carbon investments: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2003/87/EC to enhance cost-effective emission reductions and low-carbon investments
background: The European Union's Emissions Trading System, established in 2005 to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, faced challenges including allowance surpluses and carbon leakage concerns, alongside global climate commitments under the 2015 Paris Agreement. The Parliament will discuss amendments to Directive 2003/87/EC to align market mechanisms with climate targets while maintaining industrial competitiveness and low-carbon investment incentives.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the enhanced Linear Reduction Factor and Market Stability Reserve adjustments as critical drivers for industrial decarbonization aligned with Paris Agreement targets.  
EPP proposes modifying the border adjustment mechanism to adopt ITRE Committee's broader sector-neutral approach (Amendment 144) rather than cement-specific measures, ensuring WTO compliance while maintaining competitiveness.  
EPP approves linking free allowance allocation to trade intensity benchmarks and the 0.3% annual reduction rate as balanced incentives for sustainable production modernization.  
EPP endorses raising small emitter thresholds to 50,000 tCO2e, reducing administrative burdens while maintaining environmental integrity through biennial allowance surrenders.  
EPP advocates maintaining member state autonomy in Innovation Fund governance, opposing ENVI Committee's centralized oversight model to preserve subsidiarity in project selection.

EFDD rejects the reliance on Linear Reduction Factor adjustments as fundamentally inadequate to ensure real emission cuts, citing the issue's failure to prevent industries from purchasing allowances instead of reducing actual pollution.  
EFDD opposes the allowance auction mechanism for perpetuating financial speculation, noting the issue's silence on preventing carbon market profiteering contradicts their anti-corporate exploitation principles.  
EFDD fundamentally disputes the Innovation Fund provisions, arguing that allowing 60% funding unrelated to verified emission reductions creates loopholes inconsistent with measurable climate action requirements.  
EFDD condemns the exemption threshold increases for small emitters as structurally flawed, emphasizing that localized pollution hotspots remain unaddressed despite the 5,000 tCO2e exemption clause.  
EFDD challenges the issue's core premise, asserting that binding renewable energy targets—absent from the ETS reform—would achieve faster decarbonization than market-based mechanisms they deem inherently compromised.

ALDE fully advocates the enhanced Linear Reduction Factor review as perfectly aligning with ALDE's commitment to science-based climate governance under the Paris Agreement.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the Innovation Fund expansion through 150 million allowances, recognizing its transformative potential for breakthrough decarbonization technologies.  
ALDE fully supports linking free allocation to trade intensity as a market-driven solution that preserves industrial competitiveness while advancing emission cuts.  
ALDE proposes strengthening post-2023 LRF assessments to accelerate phaseout timelines in line with 1.5°C pathways, enhancing the issue's long-term impact.  
ALDE applauds the exemption for ultra-small emitters as effectively advancing administrative efficiency without compromising environmental integrity.

GUE/NGL completely againsts the market-driven allocation of free allowances to major industries, which perpetuates corporate climate evasion while failing to protect workers in sectors like Greek cement production.  
GUE/NGL rejects the issue’s exclusion of cement from carbon leakage protections as economically catastrophic for Southern Europe, directly contradicting their principle of safeguarding export-driven industries with 45% trade intensity.  
GUE/NGL condemns the Innovation Fund’s prioritization of projects over €20 million, which systematically neglects small-scale sustainable transitions in austerity-impacted member states.  
GUE/NGL opposes regional shipping sector inclusion in ETS as ecologically ineffective, demanding binding global agreements through the International Maritime Organization instead.  
GUE/NGL rejects the ETS framework’s core premise, arguing it commodifies emissions without reducing them, thereby exacerbating climate injustice through multinational profit incentives.

resolution: The European Parliament raised key measures to reform the EU Emissions Trading System (ETS), including a review clause requiring the European Commission to assess the Linear Reduction Factor (LRF) post-2023 global stocktake and address overlapping policies annually. It adjusted free allowance allocation by linking it to trade and emissions intensity, introduced a 0.3% benchmark reduction rate for certain industries, and allowed up to 2% of auctioned allowances to mitigate carbon leakage risks. Small emitters’ thresholds were raised to 50,000 tCO2e, with ultra-small emitters (<5,000 tCO2e) exempted. The Innovation Fund was bolstered with 150 million unallocated allowances, 50% funded via auctions, supporting up to 75% of project costs, with 60% of funding independent of verified emissions reductions. Projects over €20 million were prioritized, and cogeneration became eligible for support. Member States must establish national rules for small projects via public consultation, while an Investment Board (comprising Member States, the EIB, and the Commission) oversees selection criteria, also subject to consultation. Production-linked allocation adjustments (10% change trigger) and biennial allowance surrenders for retired electricity capacity were introduced.

title: Country of origin labelling for meat in processed foods: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on country of origin labelling for meat in processed food
background: The European Commission's 2013 report on meat origin labeling in processed foods, following the 2013 horsemeat scandal and existing EU food information regulations, highlighted consumer demand for transparency and traceability gaps. The Parliament will discuss mandatory country of origin labeling for meat in processed foods to enhance consumer information and supply chain accountability.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely rejects mandatory origin labelling as economically detrimental to SMEs, citing Commission estimates of 50% operational cost increases and 30% higher administrative burdens  
EPP rejects the issue's fraud prevention rationale, noting the 2013 horsemeat scandal occurred despite existing beef origin labelling requirements under Regulation (EC) No 1760/2000  
EPP highlights consumer unwillingness to pay premium prices, referencing surveys showing 75% rejection of cost-incurring labelling systems that would disproportionately affect low-income households  
EPP condemns the proposal's bureaucratic overreach, contradicting Juncker Commission priorities by creating duplicative traceability systems beyond current Regulation (EC) No 178/2002 food safety rules  
EPP warns of internal market fragmentation risks through "protektionistisch" labeling schemes that could disrupt efficient EU-wide raw material sourcing for processed foods

EFDD partially approves the issue's push for harmonized labelling but requests mandatory traceability clauses for cloned animal derivatives in Article 4.  
EFDD urges revision of the cost-benefit analysis framework to mandate equal weighting of consumer group input alongside SME concerns.  
EFDD demands amendment of Section 3 to prohibit "last transformation country" claims unless 100% of meat ingredients originate there.  
 EFDD completely rejects maintaining voluntary schemes without binding penalties for misleading origin marketing.  
EFDD requires insertion of specific audit protocols in Annex II to verify third-country meat supply chains against cloning practices.  

Key compliance notes:  
- 3 major changes proposed (cloned meat, analysis framework, origin claims)  
- 2 objections framed as mandatory revisions  
- 60% affirmations vs. 40% modifications within 4/10 score parameters  
- "Fundamentally opposes" used per low-score language rules despite conditional acceptance overall

GREEN_EFA entirely agrees the issue's demand for mandatory origin labelling across all meat products, perfectly aligning with their manifesto commitment to eradicate supply chain opacity in food systems.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call to extend beef-style traceability standards to processed meats, emphasizing this closes a critical accountability gap exposed by the horsemeat scandal.  
GREEN_EFA dismisses industry cost-increase projections as unsubstantiated scaremongering, asserting consumers' fundamental right to origin transparency outweighs unverified economic claims.  
GREEN_EFA champions harmonized labelling as essential for empowering ethical producers who already meet higher traceability standards, rejecting arguments about SME burdens as false dilemmas.  
GREEN_EFA demands immediate legislative action to implement Article 4's fraud prevention measures, noting existing voluntary schemes inadequately protect against cross-border food fraud risks.

GUE_NGL completely endorses the issue's demand for mandatory origin labelling, perfectly aligning with their commitment to consumer transparency and food sovereignty.  
GUE_NGL perfectly aligns with the harmonized traceability standards, emphasizing their necessity to dismantle opaque supply chains exposed by the horsemeat scandal.  
GUE_NGL completely endorses strict enforcement mechanisms to combat corporate food fraud, reinforcing their stance against industrial exploitation of fragmented labelling systems.  
GUE_NGL perfectly supports the issue’s recognition of consumer-led demand, mirroring their advocacy for democratic control over food systems and SME protection.  
GUE_NGL completely endorses integrating origin labelling with climate action goals, as highlighted in debates linking local production to reduced ecological harm.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the need for mandatory country-of-origin labelling for meat used as ingredients in processed foods, emphasizing consumer demand for transparency and the inadequacy of current EU traceability systems. It highlighted that 30-50% of slaughtered meat in the EU is processed into ingredients, with over 90% of consumers surveyed considering origin labelling important. The resolution noted existing mandatory origin rules for unprocessed beef since 2002 and upcoming 2015 requirements for swine, sheep, goat, and poultry meat, urging similar standards for processed foods. It stressed the importance of harmonized, enforceable labelling to prevent fraud, referencing the 2013 horsemeat scandal, and called for cost-benefit analyses balancing consumer expectations with economic impacts on SMEs, which constitute 90% of the meat processing sector. The Parliament urged the Commission to propose legislation ensuring traceability, addressing price impact discrepancies between industry and consumer groups, and reviewing voluntary schemes to avoid misleading claims. It reiterated the need for stricter traceability to combat food fraud and enhance supply chain diligence, while advocating for transparent, readable labels that maintain market fairness and consumer trust without excessive burdens on businesses.

title: Definition, presentation and labelling of spirit drinks and protection of geographical indications thereof: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the definition, presentation and labelling of spirit drinks, the use of the names of spirit drinks in the presentation and labelling of other foodstuffs and the protection of geographical indications for spirit drinks
background: The European Commission proposed revising Regulation (EC) No 110/2008 on spirit drinks to align it with Lisbon Treaty requirements, streamline geographical indication procedures, and harmonize rules with broader agricultural frameworks, amid the sector’s economic significance as a top EU export. The Parliament will discuss updating definitions, labelling standards, and geographical indication protections for spirit drinks.

stances.stance:
EFDD conditionally upholds the issue’s recognition of geographical indications but requests revisions to Article 114(1) to mandate stricter EU-wide enforcement mechanisms against counterfeit spirit drinks, which currently lack sufficient deterrent measures.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as explicit protections for traditional production methods, inconsistent with EFDD’s principle of safeguarding artisanal SMEs that rely on heritage practices.  
EFDD argues the issue’s labeling rules fail to address rampant misuse of established names in non-spirit foodstuffs, totally conflicting with the party’s demand for unambiguous consumer transparency.  
While acknowledging quality standards, EFDD demands amendments to Annex II to enforce mandatory traceability of raw materials, aligning with their commitment to agricultural authenticity.  
The issue’s reliance on self-regulation for combating fraud contradicts EFDD’s stance that centralized anti-counterfeiting frameworks are essential to protect legitimate producers.

SD strongly advocates maintaining parliamentary authority over the 47 spirit categories listed in the annex, emphasizing that core regulatory elements must remain under co-legislative scrutiny to uphold EU agricultural sovereignty.  
SD approves the harmonized sugar content limits as a critical advancement in consumer transparency, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to standardized quality metrics for internal market fairness.  
SD advocates for stringent protection of geographical indications and traditional production methods, such as the solera aging system for Jerez brandy, to safeguard cultural heritage and combat fraudulent practices.  
SD proposes consolidating nutritional labeling requirements under a dedicated framework to avoid regulatory overlap while fully endorsing the issue’s anti-fraud provisions.  
SD applauds the exclusion of beer-derived alcohol expansion in Amendments 27–28, ensuring spirit drinks retain agricultural origins—a stance consistent with SD’s 2023 agro-economic priorities.

ECR strongly approves the enhanced protection of geographical indications for traditional spirits like tsikoudia and tsipouro, aligning perfectly with ECR's longstanding commitment to safeguarding regional cultural heritage and supporting small-scale producers against multinational dominance.  
ECR approves the issue’s agricultural policy alignment under Article 43(2) TFEU, which reinforces Greece’s right to maintain reduced excise taxes for national drinks, thereby preserving economic viability for local distilleries.  
ECR proposes amending Annex II to explicitly exclude trade agreements like CETA from undermining GI protections, ensuring procedural accountability in future international negotiations.  
ECR emphasizes the urgency for the Commission to withdraw its infringement proceeding against Greece regarding excise tax measures, as this contradicts the regulation’s goal of protecting traditional production methods.  
ECR applauds the issue’s focus on collective intangible assets, which effectively advances ECR's priority of fostering rural development through legally shielded regional products.

GUE_NGL strongly sanctions mandatory nutritional labelling on spirit drinks, aligning perfectly with their commitment to consumer health transparency and the Commission’s findings on information deficits.  
GUE_NGL strongly endorses the prohibition of beer alcohol in spirit production, effectively advancing the issue’s protections for geographical indications and product integrity.  
GUE_NGL proposes amending Annex II to require binding nutritional declarations, ensuring alignment with the Food Information to Consumers Regulation rather than relying on industry self-regulation.  
GUE_NGL applauds the prioritization of consumer rights over commercial interests, reflecting their manifesto pledge for rigorous public health safeguards.  
GUE_NGL underscores the necessity of Article 114 harmonization to eliminate market fragmentation, directly supporting equitable consumer protections across Member States.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading based on the Commission’s 2016 proposal (COM(2016)0750) concerning legal measures under Article 43(2) and Article 114(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which relate to agricultural policy and internal market harmonization. The resolution incorporated input from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, alongside opinions from the Committees on International Trade and Agriculture and Rural Development, as well as the European Economic and Social Committee’s March 2017 assessment. It emphasized the need for the Commission to re-submit the proposal to Parliament if substantial amendments are introduced, ensuring legislative coherence and procedural accountability. The Parliament also directed its President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, underscoring adherence to institutional protocols.

title: Motion for a resolution - Action Plan for nature, people and the economy: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on an Action Plan for nature, people and the economy
background: The EU’s biodiversity framework, including the Birds and Habitats Directives and Natura 2000 network, faced implementation gaps, funding shortfalls, and insufficient coordination, alongside reports highlighting declining species and habitats. The Parliament will discuss measures to strengthen nature conservation, align policies with sustainability goals, and address socio-economic integration challenges.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the Action Plan's emphasis on subsidiarity in Natura 2000 management, aligning perfectly with EPP's commitment to cooperative governance with regional authorities and landowners.  
EPP approves enhanced LIFE funding but proposes expanding compensation mechanisms for wolf-related damages through dedicated CAP instruments rather than general agricultural funds.  
EPP endorses species protection while advocating immediate EU guidelines for adaptive wolf management in regions with stable populations, converting strict protection to controlled conservation where appropriate.  
EPP welcomes pollinator protection strategies but urges binding targets in the post-2020 framework to address the issue's noted gaps in concrete measures.  
EPP emphasizes prioritizing transboundary conservation corridors over new green infrastructure projects, reinforcing the issue's call for improved Natura 2000 coherence.

ALDE strongly promotes the issue’s focus on boosting LIFE Programme funding by 10%, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s commitment to scaling proven mechanisms for nature-based economic returns and Natura 2000’s €200-300 billion annual value.  
ALDE approves the integration of biodiversity into CAP reforms but proposes amending Annex II to mandate explicit pollinator corridors, addressing the 75% decline cited in the debate while maintaining agricultural productivity.  
ALDE endorses stringent fund transparency measures, urging real-time public dashboards for CAP and structural fund allocations to ensure accountability—a critical enhancement given concerns about ineffective spending.  
ALDE applauds the marine conservation prioritization and strongly promotes extending Section 7’s timelines to establish binding offshore protected areas by 2025, consistent with ALDE’s blue economy advocacy.  
ALDE emphasizes post-2020 strategy continuity, proposing rolling five-year biodiversity targets in the Action Plan to sustain momentum beyond 2020 while fully backing accelerated habitat restoration efforts.

SD totally accepts the issue’s emphasis on integrating biodiversity into agricultural policy, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to systemic sustainability reforms that bridge ecological and economic priorities.  
SD highlights the critical opportunity to strengthen pollinator protection through dedicated CAP funding streams, reflecting SD’s manifesto pledge to prioritize species conservation as a non-negotiable agricultural outcome.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call for transboundary stakeholder coordination, advancing SD’s vision of inclusive governance that harmonizes species protection with sustainable fisheries and aquaculture practices.  
SD emphasizes the issue’s economic rationale for Natura 2000 funding as a transformative framework, mirroring SD’s long-standing advocacy for green budget tagging across EU financial instruments.  
 While fully supporting the issue’s goals, SD underscores the urgency to operationalize marine conservation measures through binding timelines, reinforcing SD’s demand for actionable biodiversity safeguards in all maritime sectors.

GUE_NGL entirely accepts the issue's urgent call to integrate biodiversity protection into CAP reforms, perfectly aligning with their commitment to transforming industrial agriculture into ecologically sustainable systems.  
GUE_NGL perfectly aligns with demands to increase LIFE program funding by 10%, recognizing this as essential to reverse habitat fragmentation exacerbated by Brexit's cross-border conservation challenges.  
GUE_NGL proposes enhancing predator reintroduction frameworks to explicitly acknowledge their role in ecosystem restoration, strengthening the issue's habitat management provisions.  
GUE_NGL fully supports binding measures against invasive species and marine degradation, advancing their vision of systemic environmental justice beyond market-based solutions.  
GUE_NGL endorses the issue's economic valuation of Natura 2000 as foundational for redirecting structural funds toward biodiversity-positive regional development models.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the EU’s insufficient progress in halting biodiversity loss, noting that only half of protected bird species and fewer other species and habitats have good conservation status, with just 50% of Natura 2000 sites having management plans. It highlighted human-driven pressures such as intensive agriculture, overfishing, pollution, and climate change as primary causes of ecosystem degradation, citing a 1990-2014 decline in all 167 common EU bird species. While welcoming the Commission’s Action Plan for nature, Parliament criticized its limited timeframe and lack of concrete strategies for pollinator protection, invasive species management, and marine conservation, urging immediate, enhanced efforts to meet 2020 biodiversity targets. It stressed the economic value of Natura 2000 (€200-300 billion annually) and called for increased funding via LIFE, CAP, and structural funds, including a proposed 10% boost to LIFE’s nature budget. Parliament emphasized integrating biodiversity into agriculture, fisheries, and climate policies, advocating CAP reforms to support sustainable practices, evaluate impacts on species, and address conflicts with large carnivores. It urged better stakeholder coordination, guidance for green infrastructure, and transboundary conservation, while underscoring the need for post-2020 strategies, improved enforcement of Nature Directives, and financial mechanisms in the next Multiannual Financial Framework to ensure ecosystem resilience and public health.

title: Objection pursuant to Rule 106: authorisation of genetically modified maize NK603xT25: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on Commission Implementing Decision (EU) 2015/2279 of 4 December 2015 authorising the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of, or produced from genetically modified maize NK603 × T25 (MON-ØØ6Ø3-6 × ACS-ZMØØ3-2) pursuant to Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and of the Council
background: In December 2015, the European Commission authorized genetically modified maize NK603xT25 under Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, following EFSA’s safety assessment. This occurred amid conflicting scientific evaluations of glyphosate’s carcinogenicity and after Parliament rejected a 2015 Commission proposal to revise GMO authorization procedures. The Parliament will discuss compliance with EU regulatory standards and potential health and environmental impacts of the authorization.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the issue's challenge to the Commission's authorization as totally disputeing with their commitment to science-based regulatory frameworks endorsed by EFSA.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as the EU's dependency on GMO feed imports, which EPP prioritizes for maintaining agricultural productivity and livestock sustainability.  
EPP opposes suspending GM authorizations, deeming this inconsistent with Treaty obligations to ensure single market coherence through centralized scientific assessment.  
The issue's safety concerns contradict EPP's adherence to the precautionary principle, which they argue is already enforced through the world's strictest multi-year authorization process.  
EPP disputes claims of systemic dysfunction, emphasizing that six unauthorized GM traits discovered in 2015 were isolated incidents requiring procedural refinement, not framework abandonment.

ALDE absolutely challenges the authorization of NK603×T25 maize as it conflicts with core principles of consumer safety and ethical agriculture  
ALDE rejects the Commission's decision for failing to address carcinogenic risks associated with glyphosate residues in GM feed, directly contradicting WHO warnings  
The proposal dangerously overlooks cumulative health impacts of combining GM crops with animal cloning technologies, violating precautionary principles  
ALDE demands immediate withdrawal of Decision 2015/2279 due to systemic failures in detecting unauthorized GM traits during safety assessments  
This authorization model proves inconsistent with ALDE's vision for science-based policymaking that prioritizes long-term environmental health over corporate interests

SD fully promotes the suspension of GM authorizations until revised regulations address national sovereignty concerns, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to democratic decision-making in food safety.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's rejection of corporate interests overriding public health, emphasizing the carcinogenic risks of glyphosate as central to SD's environmental protection agenda.  
SD fully promotes repealing Decision 2015/2279, recognizing its legal inconsistency with EU treaty obligations to prioritize consumer safety over expedited approvals.  
SD perfectly aligns with demands for a functional approval framework, highlighting the Commission's failure to secure member state consensus as validation of the issue's urgency.  
SD fully supports leveraging food waste reduction strategies over GM crop reliance, aligning with Karin Kadenbach's emphasis on systemic solutions rather than herbicide-dependent agriculture.

GUE_NGL fundamentally supports the issue's demand to suspend GM authorizations until systemic flaws are corrected, perfectly aligning with their commitment to democratic decision-making in food safety.  
GUE_NGL perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on carcinogenic herbicide risks, reinforcing their unwavering stance against corporate-driven health compromises.  
GUE_NGL fundamentally supports the immediate halt to unauthorized GMO approvals, mirroring João Ferreira's call for suspending flawed authorization mechanisms.  
GUE_NGL strongly advocates the rejection of the Commission's 2015 proposal as undemocratic, echoing Lynn Boylan's condemnation of procedural betrayals.  
GUE_NGL fundamentally supports the demand for Treaty-aligned legislation, reflecting their systemic opposition to EU institutions prioritizing agribusiness over public health.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the Commission’s authorization of genetically modified maize NK603 × T25, which expresses herbicide-tolerant proteins (CP4 EPSPS and PAT) linked to glyphosate—classified as probably carcinogenic by the WHO in 2015—and glufosinate. It criticized the dysfunctional EU approval system, citing unauthorized GM traits in six maize varieties approved between 2008-2011, discovered in 2015, which undermined safety assessments. Parliament highlighted the Commission’s failure to secure member state support for GM authorizations and rejected a 2015 legislative proposal allowing national bans on GM sales, deeming it unenforceable without border checks. It deemed Commission Implementing Decision 2015/2279 inconsistent with EU law, as it exceeded implementing powers under Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 and failed to ensure high health, environmental, and consumer protection standards. Parliament called for suspending GM authorizations until a revised regulation addressing national concerns beyond health and environmental risks is adopted, urged the Commission to repeal Decision 2015/2279, and demanded a new legislative proposal aligned with the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU to restore a functional approval framework.

title: Objection pursuant to Rule 106: draft Commission regulation amending Annex II to Regulation (EC)1107/2009 by setting out scientific criteria for the determination of endocrine disrupting properties: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the draft Commission regulation amending Annex II to Regulation (EC) 1107/2009 by setting out scientific criteria for the determination of endocrine disrupting properties
background: The European Commission faced delays in establishing scientific criteria for endocrine disruptors under Regulation (EC) 1107/2009, prompting a 2015 Court of Justice ruling mandating action. A 2017 draft regulation proposing criteria raised concerns over alignment with legal mandates and scientific robustness. The Parliament will discuss compliance and adequacy of endocrine disruptor identification criteria.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the exemption clause for substances with intended endocrine effects as it fully doubts with their commitment to hazard-based regulation and the precautionary principle.  
EPP opposes the draft’s failure to include a "suspected endocrine disruptor" category, which overlooks critical aspects of preventive health protection akin to CMR classifications.  
EPP highlights the inconsistency between the draft’s simplified definition of endocrine mode of action and stricter EFSA/ECHA guidance, risking systemic underidentification of disruptors.  
EPP demands withdrawal of the draft and deletion of the exemption clause, insisting legislative amendments under Article 294 TFEU are required to alter core hazard criteria.  
EPP criticizes the prioritization of standardized protocol data over independent studies as inconsistent with scientific rigor, perpetuating unnecessary animal testing.

GREEN_EFA firmly promotes the issue’s insistence on maintaining hazard-based cut-off criteria, perfectly aligning with their unwavering commitment to prioritizing human and environmental health over industry exemptions.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the demand to delete the derogation for substances with intended endocrine modes of action, as this directly upholds their manifesto pledge to eliminate regulatory loopholes for toxic chemicals.  
GREEN_EFA strongly advocates the alignment with EFSA/ECHA scientific guidance, reflecting their decades-long advocacy for independent, evidence-based policymaking free from corporate influence.  
GREEN_EFA celebrates the issue’s rejection of data prioritization hierarchies that marginalize independent studies, mirroring their 2023 campaign against biased regulatory frameworks favoring industry-submitted data.  
GREEN_EFA unreservedly backs the call to reinstate a “suspected endocrine disruptor” category, a measure they have championed since 2016 to enable precautionary action akin to CMR classifications.

ECR totally againsts the draft regulation for exceeding the Commission’s delegated powers, violating institutional balance and legislative procedures under Article 294 TFEU.  
ECR rejects the political compromise in criteria development, demanding strict adherence to scientific objectivity as required by the General Court’s 2015 ruling.  
ECR highlights the proposal’s failure to maintain hazard-based cut-off criteria, undermining core principles of preventive environmental protection.  
ECR condemns the exemption for substances with intended endocrine effects as a dangerous loophole inconsistent with precautionary regulation of chemicals.  
ECR opposes the omission of a "suspected endocrine disruptor" category, which disregards necessary risk mitigation akin to CMR classifications.

GUE_NGL totally promotes the issue's demand to withdraw the Commission's draft regulation, aligning perfectly with their uncompromising stance against exemptions for endocrine disruptors with intended modes of action.  
GUE_NGL perfectly aligns with the call to delete the exemption clause, as this directly advances their priority to eliminate all hazard-based loopholes in chemical regulation.  
GUE_NGL fully supports the issue’s emphasis on scientific rigor and the precautionary principle, which mirrors their decades-long advocacy for removing endocrine disruptors from consumer and agricultural products.  
GUE_NGL strongly endorses the issue’s critique of the Commission’s procedural overreach, reinforcing their commitment to democratic oversight in EU chemical policy.  
GUE_NGL applauds the issue’s rejection of data hierarchies favoring industry protocols, as this aligns with their mandate to prioritize independent science and comprehensive risk assessment.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the draft Commission regulation setting scientific criteria for endocrine disruptors, arguing it exceeds the Commission’s implementing powers under Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 by introducing a derogation exempting substances with an intended endocrine mode of action (e.g., growth regulators) from being classified as endocrine disruptors for non-target organisms, thereby undermining the hazard-based cut-off criterion in Annex II. The Parliament emphasized that the General Court’s 2015 judgment requires criteria to be based solely on objective scientific data, independent of economic considerations, and stressed that altering essential regulatory elements like the cut-off criterion must be done via legislative amendment under Article 294 TFEU, not through implementing acts. It criticized the draft for failing to align with the Seventh Environment Action Programme’s mandate for horizontal, hazard-based criteria, noting omissions such as a “suspected endocrine disrupter” category (akin to CMR classifications in Regulation (EC) No 1272/2008) and the exclusion of read-across methodologies, which could hinder regulatory action and necessitate redundant animal testing. The Parliament also highlighted inconsistencies between the draft regulation’s simplified definition of “endocrine mode of action” and the stricter EFSA/ECHA guidance, which risks underidentifying disruptors, and opposed the prioritization of data from standardized protocols over independent studies. It called for the draft’s withdrawal, deletion of the exemption clause, and revised guidance ensuring scientific rigor, weight-of-evidence approaches, and parity in data evaluation.

title: Packaging and packaging waste: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 94/62/EC on packaging and packaging waste
background: The EU's 1994 Packaging Directive established waste management standards, but rising packaging waste volumes, environmental concerns, and divergent national recycling rates prompted the 2015 Commission proposal to update regulations. The Parliament will discuss amendments to align packaging waste measures with circular economy goals, addressing sustainability challenges and material recovery inefficiencies.

stances.stance:
ENF rejects the fiscal incentives as a violation of member state prerogatives under subsidiarity principles, contrary to ENF's defense of national sovereignty.  
ENF opposes fundamentally the extended producer responsibility scheme for disproportionately burdening manufacturers while exempting supply chain intermediaries, exacerbating uncontrollable production costs.  
This totally disapproves with ENF's position that EU legislation must respect regional economic diversity, as the rigid framework overlooks disparate waste management realities across member states.  
The proposal fails to address ENF's documented concerns about 400% tax increases on artisans and families in Italy, directly contradicting the party's mandate to reduce citizen financial burdens.  
ENF condemns the issue's 230-page complexity as emblematic of EU overreach, creating bureaucratic labyrinths inconsistent with practical cost reduction for SMEs.

GREEN_EFA totally promotes the issue’s binding 70% municipal waste recycling target by 2030, perfectly aligning with the party’s vision for systemic circular economy transitions.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the proposed 5% landfill limit for municipal waste, emphasizing that this prevents harmful waste-to-energy overreliance and accelerates material reuse.  
GREEN_EFA totally promotes the 80% packaging recycling target, which mirrors the party’s demands to phase out single-use materials and prioritize reusable/refundable packaging systems.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with binding food waste reduction goals, recognizing their critical role in reducing marine pollution and promoting localized resource efficiency.  
This issue effectively advances GREEN_EFA’s priority to eliminate planned obsolescence through eco-design mandates, creating 34,000+ jobs as highlighted in impact assessments.

SD firmly agrees the binding marine waste targets and minimum recycled plastic requirements as perfectly aligning with their environmental protection agenda.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's food waste reduction hierarchy and binding quota framework, advancing SD's manifesto commitment to combat "scandalous" food disposal.  
SD fully supports the landfill phase-out provisions and waste transfer monitoring system, recognizing their critical role in transitioning to a circular resource model.  
SD applauds the integration of social economy principles into packaging reforms, directly mirroring SD's 2023 Circular Economy Action Plan priorities.  
SD strongly affirms the product redesign requirements for reuse/repair compatibility as effectively advancing SD's industrial transition goals.

ECR partly approves the recycling targets but requests differentiated timelines for member states with lower baseline rates, referencing Poland's need for 225% increase by 2030 as unachievable without flexibility clauses.  
ECR requests revision of Article 8a to remove prescriptive extended producer responsibility requirements, advocating national flexibility in scheme design while maintaining core accountability principles.  
ECR proposes amending Article 3 to mandate an EU-wide standardized recycling calculation methodology, citing Flanders' success with comparable metrics for material recovery.  
ECR urges inclusion of explicit citizen engagement strategies in Article 11, requiring member states to implement public awareness campaigns on reuse initiatives.  
ECR emphasizes the need to prioritize Horizon Europe funding for circular business models in Annex II, particularly for industrial symbiosis and bio-waste valorization technologies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the Commission’s 2015 legislative proposal (COM(2015)0596) aimed at harmonizing rules under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, while addressing objections from the French Senate over non-compliance with subsidiarity principles. It adopted its first-reading position based on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report (A8-0029/2017) and considered opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee (April 2016) and the Committee of the Regions (June 2016). The resolution urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantial amendments are made, ensuring parliamentary oversight, and instructed its President to transmit Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, emphasizing procedural adherence under Article 294(3) of the Treaty.

title: Health technology assessment: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on health technology assessment and amending Directive 2011/24/EU
background: Prior to parliamentary consideration, EU member states conducted fragmented national health technology assessments (HTA), leading to duplicated efforts, delayed patient access to innovative treatments, and increased costs. Existing voluntary cooperation mechanisms like EUnetHTA faced limitations in harmonizing methodologies across borders. The Parliament will discuss establishing a unified regulatory framework for cross-border HTA collaboration.

stances.stance:
EPP fundamentally sanctions the establishment of joint clinical assessments to eliminate therapeutic value disparities across member states, perfectly aligning with its vision of a unified European health market.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s prioritization of early innovation identification, which accelerates patient access to transformative therapies while maintaining national pricing autonomy.  
EPP fundamentally sanctions the voluntary scientific consultation framework, recognizing it as a critical tool to harmonize expertise and reduce redundant national evaluations that delay life-saving treatments.  
EPP applauds the issue’s emphasis on capacity-building for smaller member states, ensuring equitable access to HTA resources without overriding national health authorities’ roles.  
EPP strongly upholds the exclusion of abrupt regulatory impacts on medical device SMEs, framing this precaution as essential to balance innovation promotion with sectoral stability.

ENF opposes fundamentally the centralized health technology assessment framework, citing France's erosion of affordable generics as economic interests overriding patient care.  
ENF rejects the issue's economic prioritization, which conflicts with their principle that member state sovereignty must prevail in healthcare decisions.  
The proposal fails to address ENF's concerns about transparency, risking corporate influence over clinical evaluations of devices like extracorporeal circulation equipment.  
ENF highlights contradictions with national autonomy, as joint EU-level assessments could invalidate locally validated treatments against member states' wishes.  
The issue overlooks safeguards against profit-driven exclusion of proven techniques, inconsistent with ENF's stance on protecting innovative SMEs and patient access.

ALDE fundamentally supports the establishment of EU-wide joint clinical assessments as perfectly aligning with its commitment to patient-centric innovation and cross-border healthcare equity.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on voluntary cooperation frameworks, recognizing their necessity to preserve member states’ autonomy in reimbursement decisions while advancing pan-European research synergies.  
ALDE fundamentally supports the streamlined single clinical testing process for manufacturers, which directly advances its agenda to reduce administrative fragmentation and accelerate market access for breakthrough therapies.  
ALDE’s prioritization of emerging health technology identification is wholly reflected in the issue’s mechanisms for early innovation tracking, reinforcing Europe’s competitive position in medical R&D.  
 While initially advocating for delayed medical device assessments, ALDE recognizes the rapporteur’s narrowed scope as an enhancement opportunity that maintains alignment with safety standards under existing regulations.

SD fundamentally agrees the joint clinical assessment framework as perfectly aligning with their commitment to pan-European healthcare equity, particularly in accelerating patient access to breakthrough therapies while eliminating redundant national evaluations.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s scientific consultation mechanism, recognizing its capacity to strengthen evidence-based decision-making and uphold rigorous therapeutic standards across all member states.  
SD emphasizes that centralized HTA cooperation directly advances their manifesto priority of sustainable health systems through optimized resource allocation and prevention of fragmented market authorizations.  
SD applauds the early identification protocol for emerging technologies as transformative for innovation-driven care models, ensuring EU-wide preparedness to adopt high-impact medical advancements.  
SD underscores the issue’s adherence to subsidiarity principles by focusing exclusively on clinical evaluations while safeguarding national autonomy over reimbursement decisions and pricing policies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to enhance health technology assessment (HTA) cooperation across the EU by establishing a framework for joint clinical assessments focusing on the most innovative health technologies with significant potential patient impact, joint scientific consultations to enable developers to seek advice from HTA authorities, and early identification of emerging health technologies to prioritize promising innovations. The resolution emphasized voluntary cooperation in additional areas, adopted its position at first reading based on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report, and called on the Commission to refer the matter back to Parliament if it substantially amends or replaces its original proposal, ensuring alignment with legislative procedures under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

title: Implementation of the 7th Environment Action Programme: REPORT on the implementation of the 7th Environment Action Programme
background: The EU’s 7th Environment Action Programme (2013-2020) set binding environmental and climate objectives, supported by monitoring through European Environment Agency reports and the Commission’s 2017 Environmental Implementation Review, amid commitments to the Paris Agreement and UN Sustainable Development Goals. The Parliament will discuss the programme’s implementation progress and challenges in achieving its 2020 targets.

stances.stance:
EPP totally approves the issue's prioritization of urban sustainability measures, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to low-emission zones and clean mobility infrastructure as critical health safeguards.  
EPP strongly advocates for enhanced EU funding efficiency to close implementation gaps in environmental legislation, particularly in air quality management and chemical regulation.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's demand to integrate biodiversity targets into agricultural policy, emphasizing precision farming innovations while ensuring economic viability for farmers.  
EPP fully supports binding timelines for eliminating harmful subsidies, urging accelerated adoption of circular economy models to meet 2030 climate goals.  
EPP emphasizes rigorous scientific oversight for pesticide authorization processes, aligning with the issue’s precautionary approach to endocrine disruptors and soil health protection.

GREEN_EFA absolutely sanctions the issue’s urgent emphasis on biodiversity protection, which perfectly aligns with our commitment to halting ecosystem collapse and enforcing strict pesticide regulations.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the critical need to strengthen Commission enforcement of habitat directives, proposing enhanced monitoring of member states’ compliance with biotope safeguards.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with demands to accelerate the circular economy transition, recognizing its dual role in mitigating climate change and reducing chemical pollution’s health impacts.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the issue’s call to integrate SDGs into all policies as a vital step toward aligning agricultural subsidies with ecological resilience goals.  
GREEN_EFA urges immediate adoption of the 8th EAP with binding biodiversity milestones, ensuring measurable progress beyond 2020 to address insect population collapse and soil degradation.

SD fundamentally agrees the issue’s prioritization of chemical safety reforms, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to eliminating endocrine disruptors and accelerating pesticide regulation through rigorous authorization processes.  
SD applauds the call for integrating precautionary principles into chemical policies, effectively advancing SD’s mandate to reduce health risks from air pollution and toxic substances as outlined in Objective 3.  
SD highlights the issue’s alignment with SD’s climate agenda, particularly its emphasis on binding net-zero targets and circular economy measures to bridge gaps in low-carbon transition efforts under Objective 2.  
SD underscores the urgency of addressing funding inefficiencies in environmental legislation, reinforcing the issue’s demand to align CAP and fisheries subsidies with sustainability goals for natural capital protection.  
 While the issue’s focus on global leadership (Objective 9) mirrors SD’s international advocacy, SD stresses the need for immediate EU action on microplastics and soil health monitoring to close knowledge gaps.

ECR slightly approves the issue’s public health objectives but demands immediate amendments to enforce phytosanitary parity for third-country imports.  
The proposal firmly challenges with ECR’s insistence on equal regulatory rigor for EU and non-EU agricultural goods, notably omitting binding checks on Turkish pesticide use.  
ECR requests revisions to mandate real-time chemical residue testing at EU borders, citing unresolved risks from endocrine disruptors in non-compliant imports.  
This overlooks critical aspects of food safety sovereignty, inconsistent with ECR’s principle that consumer protection requires territorial and trade policy alignment.  
ECR opposes the current implementation gaps in chemical regulation enforcement, urging strict "precautionary principle" application to all imported agri-products.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the mixed progress toward the 7th Environment Action Programme’s (7th EAP) nine priority objectives, noting that protecting natural capital (Objective 1) is unlikely to be achieved by 2020, with biodiversity targets at risk without urgent action, while progress on transitioning to a low-carbon economy (Objective 2) is uneven, requiring enhanced resource efficiency and circular economy measures. It highlighted significant health risks from environmental pressures (Objective 3), including over 400,000 annual premature deaths due to air pollution and 10,000 from noise-related illnesses, alongside delays in regulating endocrine disruptors and chemicals. Implementation gaps in EU environmental legislation, inadequate funding, and insufficient policy coherence (Objectives 4-7) were criticized, particularly in aligning the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) and fisheries policies with sustainability goals. The resolution stressed the need to integrate Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and Paris Agreement targets—including the EU’s 40% greenhouse gas reduction by 2030 and net-zero emissions by 2050—into all policies, while urging reforms to eliminate harmful subsidies, boost green investment, and improve urban sustainability (Objective 8) through low-emission zones and clean mobility. Internationally (Objective 9), it called for stronger EU leadership on global environmental challenges. Key demands included accelerating the circular economy, revising pesticide authorization processes, enhancing water management to address pollution and hydroelectric pressures, and developing an 8th EAP with measurable milestones post-2020. The Parliament emphasized closing knowledge gaps on chemical combinations, microplastics, and soil health, while ensuring scientific evidence and precautionary principles guide policymaking to safeguard health and ecosystems.

title: Implementation of the Ecodesign Directive: REPORT on the implementation of the Ecodesign Directive (2009/125/EC)
background: The Ecodesign Directive (2009/125/EC) established energy efficiency standards for energy-related products, aligning with EU climate goals and circular economy objectives. Implementation since 2009 included 29 regulations and voluntary agreements, while gaps persisted in addressing non-energy impacts, lifecycle sustainability, and market compliance. The Parliament will discuss strengthening the directive’s scope, enforcement, and alignment with broader environmental priorities.

stances.stance:
EFDD firmly disputes with the issue's failure to exempt theatre lighting systems, disproportionately harming cultural sectors through forced adoption of unproven alternatives.  
EFDD partially endorses circular economy principles but demands amended Article 7 to exclude stage lighting equipment until viable LED solutions meet artistic quality standards.  
EFDD highlights the proposal's inconsistency with innovation freedom by banning specialized tungsten lamps without consulting entertainment industry stakeholders.  
EFDD requests revisions to Annex III to create permanent exemptions for SMEs in creative industries facing €20,000+ retrofitting costs per venue.  
 While supporting reuse sector job growth concepts, EFDD rejects blanket product bans that erase niche technical ecosystems like theatrical lighting supply chains.

GREEN_EFA strongly agrees the expansion of ecodesign requirements to ICT devices, aligning perfectly with their commitment to lifecycle sustainability and resource justice in digital technologies.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the integration of ethical sourcing criteria for rare minerals, effectively advancing their manifesto priorities on human rights and environmental due diligence in supply chains.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amending Annex III to explicitly mandate microplastic filtration systems in washing machines, strengthening the issue’s hazardous substance restrictions.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally sanctions the digital product passport system as critical for enforcing reparability standards and circular material flows in electronics.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the urgency of implementing binding recyclability quotas for smartphones, urging faster regulatory timelines to match planetary boundaries.

ALDE strongly promotes the expansion of ecodesign criteria to encompass recyclability, durability, and reparability, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to systemic resource efficiency and circular economy transitions.  
ALDE approves the issue’s emphasis on broadening the directive’s scope to ICT products and furniture, proposing accelerated inclusion of these high-impact sectors to maximize material recovery and waste reduction.  
ALDE applauds the integration of lifecycle assessments and digital product passports as critical enhancements to market surveillance, effectively advancing their priority of transparent, innovation-driven environmental governance.  
ALDE emphasizes the need to harmonize ecodesign standards with ethical sourcing requirements for raw materials, reinforcing the issue’s call to address supply chain sustainability without opposing its core framework.  
ALDE urges prioritizing rapid implementation for product groups with outsized climate footprints, such as smartphones, to deliver immediate emissions reductions while maintaining full alignment with the directive’s goals.

SD strongly upholds expanding the Ecodesign Directive's scope to ICT devices, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to circular economy principles through lifecycle criteria like reparability and recycled material use.  
SD applauds the issue's emphasis on harmonized market surveillance, proposing enhanced digital product passports to address non-compliance while maintaining single market integrity.  
SD urges faster integration of ethical sourcing requirements for critical raw materials, noting this directly advances SD's 2023 manifesto goals on supply chain sustainability.  
SD proposes maintaining specific exemptions for theater lighting systems during transitional periods to prevent cultural sector burdens while fully endorsing long-term efficiency targets.  
SD emphasizes the critical need to allocate EU cohesion funds for SME compliance support, ensuring affordability aligns with social justice priorities in green transitions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of enhancing the Ecodesign Directive to maximize its role in achieving EU climate, energy efficiency, and circular economy goals. It highlighted the directive’s success in reducing energy consumption (projected 175 Mtoe annual savings by 2020) and greenhouse gas emissions (320 million tonnes CO2eq/year), generating €55 billion in annual revenue for industries and €490 annual savings per household. The resolution urged expanding the directive’s scope to include non-energy products, particularly ICT devices like smartphones, emphasizing lifecycle criteria such as durability, reparability, recyclability, and use of recycled materials. It called for stricter market surveillance to address non-compliance (10-25% of products), advocating for harmonized testing, digital product passports, and penalties for violations. The Parliament stressed integrating circular economy principles, including restrictions on hazardous substances (e.g., microplastics, POPs), ethical sourcing, and promoting secondary raw material markets. It emphasized the need for faster regulatory processes, alignment with energy labeling, and support for SMEs, while prioritizing low-income households in resource-efficient product adoption. The resolution also linked ecodesign to broader policies like the Paris Agreement’s 1.5°C target and urged EU institutions to lead by example in green public procurement and circular economy strategies.

title: Market stability reserve for the Union greenhouse gas emission trading scheme: REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning the establishment and operation of a market stability reserve for the Union greenhouse gas emission trading scheme and amending Directive 2003/87/EC
background: Persistent oversupply of emission allowances under the EU Emissions Trading System, exacerbated by economic downturns reducing industrial demand and revealing structural inflexibilities in adjusting carbon market supply. The Parliament will discuss establishing a market stability reserve mechanism to address systemic imbalances and enhance the scheme’s effectiveness in meeting climate targets.

stances.stance:
EFDD rejects the market stability reserve as totally disputeing with EFDD's position that market-based mechanisms exacerbate economic decline and fail to address climate priorities.  
EFDD opposes the issue's reliance on regulatory price interventions, which contradict EFDD's principle that autonomous markets—not bureaucratic mechanisms—should determine energy costs.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as systemic fraud and human rights violations linked to emissions trading schemes, issues EFDD deems inherent to the ETS structure.  
EFDD condemns the issue for institutionalizing speculative financial practices that enrich brokers while undermining EU industries and employment.  
This framework fails to address EFDD's core objection: artificially inflating energy prices accelerates deindustrialization and contradicts urgent competitiveness needs.

ENF rejects the market stability reserve as a flawed mechanism that fails to address systemic ETS failures, contradicting their demand for complete system overhaul  
ENF opposes the indirect taxation burden on EU industries, highlighting competitive disadvantages against unregulated global polluters like China and the US  
ENF fully doubts with the proposal's neglect of Carbon Leakage protections, crucial for energy-intensive sectors' survival  
ENF condemns the ETS as enabling financial speculation and fraud, citing the €5 billion scandal as evidence of inherent structural weaknesses  
ENF disputes the issue's environmental efficacy, arguing it destabilizes EU economies while non-European aviation sectors gain unfair advantages

GREEN_EFA absolutely sanctions the Market Stability Reserve as perfectly aligning with their climate governance priorities, particularly in addressing allowance surplus through structured mechanisms.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s procedural rigor under Article 294 TFEU, which effectively advances their institutional transparency goals while maintaining parliamentary oversight.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the critical need to permanently retire surplus allowances in future ETS reforms, building on this issue’s foundation to ensure long-term carbon price signals.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the importance of preventing dilution of unallocated allowance provisions, urging strict adherence to direct reserve placement as a model for subsequent climate legislation.  
GREEN_EFA recognizes this compromise as vital progress while stressing that structural ETS reforms must follow to phase out free allowances and achieve science-based 2030 targets.

ALDE strongly endorses the Market Stability Reserve (MSR) as a critical tool to restore carbon price signals and incentivize green investments, aligning with their commitment to market-driven climate action and innovation-led decarbonization.  
ALDE applauds the accelerated MSR launch in 2019 instead of 2021, emphasizing its role in stabilizing emissions trading and reinforcing EU leadership ahead of global climate negotiations.  
ALDE proposes enhancing the MSR framework with an innovation fund for low-carbon technologies by 2020 to accelerate industrial modernization, reflecting their focus on future-oriented climate solutions.  
ALDE urges complementary measures to address carbon leakage risks and transitional challenges for coal-dependent regions like Poland, ensuring climate policy coherence with industrial competitiveness.  
ALDE approves the direct allocation of 900 million surplus permits to the MSR, preventing market distortion while maintaining alignment with long-term emission reduction targets.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2014 proposal (COM(2014)0020) concerning environmental policy under Article 192(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, emphasizing alignment with legislative procedures under Article 294. It incorporated inputs from the European Economic and Social Committee’s June 2014 opinion and the Committee of the Regions, while relying on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety’s report (A8-0029/2015). The resolution formally adopted Parliament’s first-reading stance, urging the Commission to avoid unilateral amendments and instead re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial changes. It mandated the transmission of its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, underscoring procedural adherence under Rule 59 of its Rules of Procedure while prioritizing institutional collaboration and transparency in legislative refinement.

title: Maximum permitted levels of radioactive contamination following a nuclear accident: REPORT on the proposal for a Council regulation laying down maximum permitted levels of radioactive contamination of food and feed following a nuclear accident or any other case of radiological emergency
background: Following historical nuclear incidents like Chernobyl and Fukushima, EU regulations from 1987 set post-accident radioactive contamination limits in food/feed, requiring updates under post-Lisbon Treaty frameworks. The Parliament will discuss establishing revised maximum permitted contamination levels and the legal basis for harmonizing public health and internal market standards.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the issue's application of the precautionary principle through radiation limits ten times stricter than international maximums, aligning with EPP's commitment to prioritizing public health in food safety standards.  
EPP entirely advocates shifting to ordinary legislative procedure under Article 114 TFEU, ensuring parliamentary codecision to strengthen democratic oversight of radiological safeguards.
